choices.text: Crypta magna is a large crypt on the medial surface of the tonsil and represents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch
Lateral surface of the tonsil is covered by respiratory epithelium and is adherent to the superior constrictor
The upper pole of the tonsil is in contact with the tongue and forms the anterior tonsillar space
The tonsil is anterior to the superior constrictor and lateral to the palatoglossus muscle

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomy of the palatine tonsil is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crypta magna is a large crypt on the medial surface of the tonsil and represents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch

 

  • The medial surface of the tonsil is lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • It has 12–15 crypts, one of which is particularly large and deep, known as crypta magna or the intratonsillar cleft, and it embryologically represents the ventral portion of the second pharyngeal pouch.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral surface of the tonsil is covered by respiratory epithelium and is adherent to the superior constrictor: Incorrect The lateral surface is not lined by respiratory epithelium; it has a fibrous capsule. It is not adherent but separated by loose areolar tissue from the superior constrictor, allowing dissection during tonsillectomy.

 

Option C.  The upper pole of the tonsil is in contact with the tongue and forms the anterior tonsillar space: Incorrect. The upper pole extends into the soft palate, not the tongue.
The anterior tonsillar space is related to the lower pole, not the upper.

 

Option D. The tonsil is anterior to the superior constrictor and lateral to the palatoglossus muscle: Incorrect. The tonsil does not lie anterior to the superior constrictor. The palatoglossus is anterior to the tonsil, forming the anterior pillar.

 

 

Tonsil is related laterally to its capsule (1), loose areolar tissue containing paratonsillar vein (2), superior constrictor muscle (3), styloglossus (4), glossopharyngeal nerve (5), facial artery (6), medial pterygoid muscle (7), angle of mandible (8) and submandibular salivary gland (9), pharyngobasilar fascia (10), buccopharyngeal fascia (11).

 

Educational Objective:


Crypta magna is the largest crypt on the medial surface of the palatine tonsil and is derived from the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 257

choices.text: Oropharynx – extends from skull base to soft palate; lies opposite C1
Laryngopharynx – extends from hyoid to lower border of cricoid; lies opposite C3–C6
Nasopharynx – extends from soft palate to hyoid bone; lies opposite C2–C3
Oropharynx – extends from nasal cavity to cricoid cartilage; lies opposite C4–C6

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the part of the pharynx with its anatomical extent and vertebral level?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngopharynx – extends from hyoid to lower border of cricoid; lies opposite C3–C6.

 

 

The pharynx is a fibromuscular conduit for both air and food, extending from the base of the skull to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It is divided into three anatomical parts, each with specific boundaries and vertebral levels:

 

  1. Nasopharynx
    • Behind nasal cavity
    • Extends: Skull base → soft palate
    • Vertebral level: Opposite C1
  2. Oropharynx
    • Behind oral cavity
    • Extends: Soft palate → hyoid bone
    • Vertebral level: Opposite C2–upper C3
  3. Laryngopharynx (hypopharynx)
    • Behind larynx
    • Extends: Hyoid bone → lower border of cricoid cartilage
    • Vertebral level: C3–C6

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Oropharynx – extends from skull base to soft palate; lies opposite C1: Incorrect – This describes the nasopharynx, not the oropharynx

 

Option C. Nasopharynx – extends from soft palate to hyoid bone; lies opposite C2–C3: Incorrect – This describes the oropharynx, not the nasopharynx

 

Option D. Oropharynx – extends from nasal cavity to cricoid cartilage; lies opposite C4–C6 Incorrect – The oropharynx does not extend from nasal cavity to cricoid; that would include all three parts of the pharynx

 

Educational Objective:
 

The laryngopharynx extends from the hyoid bone to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage and lies opposite vertebrae C3 to C6.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 238.

choices.text: Mandibular nerve block to relieve referred pain
Styloid process excision via transoral or cervical approach

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with persistent dull pain in the tonsillar region and upper neck, radiating to the ipsilateral ear. The pain worsens with swallowing. On examination, transoral palpation of the tonsillar fossa elicits tenderness over a bony projection. Lateral skull X-ray reveals an elongated styloid process. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Styloid process excision via transoral or cervical approach

 

  • Definitive treatment for symptomatic Eagle syndrome

 

This patient presents with classic Eagle syndrome (styalgia):

 

  • Elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament
  • Pain in tonsillar fossa, upper neck, and ear
  • Aggravated by swallowing
  • Diagnosed by:
    • Transoral palpation of elongated process in tonsillar fossa
    • Radiographic confirmation (lateral skull or AP with open mouth)

 

 

Management:

 

  • If asymptomatic → no treatment
  • If symptomatic → surgical excision of the styloid process through:
    • Transoral (less invasive, limited exposure)
    • Cervical (better visualization, more extensive)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance and monitoring with no intervention: Only appropriate in asymptomatic individuals with incidental finding of elongated styloid

 

Option B. Mandibular nerve block to relieve referred pain: Not effective in Eagle syndrome, as the pain arises from mechanical irritation of cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, X)

 

Option D. Tonsillectomy to decompress surrounding structures: Tonsils are not the source of pain; this procedure does not relieve the underlying mechanical compression

 

Educational Objective:


Eagle syndrome (styalgia) is caused by an elongated styloid process and is treated with surgical excision in symptomatic cases.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 272

choices.text: The incidence is highest in North India due to widespread air pollution and incense use
IgA antibodies to EBV viral capsid antigen (VCA) are highly specific for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Preserved salted fish consumption is a recognized environmental risk factor for NPC due to nitrosamine exposure
Smoking tobacco is the most important and specific risk factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma worldwide

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding nasopharyngeal carcinoma is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preserved salted fish consumption is a recognized environmental risk factor for NPC due to nitrosamine exposure

 

Preserved salted fish contains nitrosamines, which are a major environmental risk factor in endemic regions

 

In endemic areas such as Southern China and Taiwan, preserved salted fish is a key dietary risk factor. It contains nitrosamines, which are potent carcinogens. Diets deficient in vitamin C fail to block the nitrosification of amines, increasing NPC risk.

 

Key Concepts from the Passage:

 

  • Highest incidence: Southern China, Taiwan, and Indonesia
  • Genetic susceptibility: Chinese origin, including migrants
  • Environmental factors:
    Preserved salted fish (nitrosamines)
    Incense and wood smoke (polycyclic hydrocarbons)
    Smoking and air pollution
  • Viral association: Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    IgA anti-EA: More specific, less sensitive
    IgA anti-VCA: More sensitive, less specific
  • Uncommon in India overall, except in the North-East (Mongoloid ethnicity)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The incidence is highest in North India due to widespread air pollution and incense use: Incorrect – NPC is uncommon in most parts of India, including the North, and is more common in the North-East among people of Mongoloid origin

 

Option B.  IgA antibodies to EBV viral capsid antigen (VCA) are highly specific for nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Incorrect – IgA antibodies to early antigen (EA) are more specific, not VCA. VCA antibodies are more sensitive but less specific

 

Option D. Smoking tobacco is the most important and specific risk factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma worldwide: Incorrect – Smoking is a risk factor, but not the most specific or strongest for NPC, especially compared to EBV infection and nitrosamine exposure

 

Educational Objective:
 

Preserved salted fish containing nitrosamines is a key environmental risk factor for nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in endemic regions like Southern China and Taiwan.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 250

choices.text: Emergency incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess
CT scan of the neck to rule out parapharyngeal abscess

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe unilateral sore throat, fever, odynophagia, and difficulty swallowing his saliva. His voice is muffled ("hot potato voice") and he complains of left ear pain. Examination reveals swelling of the left soft palate, deviation of the uvula to the right, and trismus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess

 

Correct. Standard of care for peritonsillar abscess with marked clinical features.

 

This patient has a classic presentation of peritonsillar abscess (quinsy):

 

  • Severe unilateral throat pain
  • "Hot potato voice"
  • Trismus
  • Uvula pushed to opposite side
  • Referred otalgia via glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
  • Drooling and odynophagia (patient unable to swallow saliva)

 

Management involves:

 

  • IV fluids, antibiotics, analgesia, and most importantly
  • Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of maximal bulge, just above the upper pole of the tonsil

 

Hot tonsillectomy is less commonly used due to risk of bleeding and rupture under anesthesia. Interval tonsillectomy may be considered after 4–6 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral penicillin and close outpatient follow-up: Not sufficient; this is not uncomplicated tonsillitis. A frank abscess requires drainage.

 

Option C. Immediate hot tonsillectomy: Not first-line due to risk of rupture during induction, bleeding, and technical difficulty due to inflamed tissues.

 

Option D. CT scan to rule out parapharyngeal abscess: Not needed immediately in typical cases. CT may be useful if deep neck space infection is suspected (e.g., atypical signs, no bulge, systemic deterioration).

 

Educational Objective:
 

Peritonsillar abscess presents with unilateral sore throat, uvular deviation, trismus, and muffled voice, and is best treated with incision and drainage along with IV antibiotics.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 265

choices.text: It originates from the torus tubarius and grows medially into the nasal septum
It is a benign tumor composed of vascular spaces with well-developed muscular walls, hence responds well to adrenaline
It most commonly arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae
It is a common malignant tumor of the nasopharynx seen in elderly men

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It most commonly arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae
 

Most accepted origin is near superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen, with typical lateral extension to pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae

 

JNA is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor of adolescent males. It most commonly arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen (posterior nasal cavity) and can extend into the nasopharynx, pterygopalatine fossa, pterygomaxillary fissure, infratemporal fossa, and even the cheek, displacing the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus.

 

 

Key Concepts from the Passage:

 

  • JNA: Most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx, though rare overall
  • Site of origin: Posterior nasal cavity, close to superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen
  • Growth pattern:
    • Nasal cavity → Nasopharynx → Pterygopalatine fossa
    • Lateral spread → Pterygomaxillary fossa → Infratemporal fossa → Cheek
  • Pathology:
    • Composed of vascular and fibrous tissue
    • Vessels are thin-walled, lacking smooth muscle or elastic fibers
    • Hence, bleeding is severe and adrenaline is ineffective

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It originates from the torus tubarius and grows medially into the nasal septum:  Incorrect – The torus tubarius is part of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall near the Eustachian tube, not the origin site of JNA

 

Option B. It is a benign tumor composed of vascular spaces with well-developed muscular walls, hence responds well to adrenaline: Incorrect – The vessels in JNA are lined by endothelium only, lack muscular walls, which is why bleeding is profuse and unresponsive to adrenaline

 

Option D. It is a common malignant tumor of the nasopharynx seen in elderly men: Incorrect – JNA is not malignant, and it occurs in adolescent males, not elderly men

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma arises near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen and extends into adjacent fossae, with severe bleeding due to poorly contractile vascular channels.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 246

choices.text: Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx
High-resolution CT scan of the paranasal sinuses
Trial of oral corticosteroids and saline irrigation

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought by his parents with complaints of chronic mouth breathing, snoring, and difficulty hearing. The child has a history of recurrent upper respiratory infections and poor school performance due to inattention. On physical examination, adenoid facies is noted. The physician suspects adenoid hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx
 

Reveals the size of adenoids and how much they encroach into the nasopharyngeal airway. Standard first-line imaging when endoscopy is not feasible.

 

A lateral soft tissue X-ray of the nasopharynx is a non-invasive and commonly used investigation to assess adenoid size and evaluate the degree of nasopharyngeal airway compromise, especially in uncooperative or very young children. It is a quick, accessible, and effective initial diagnostic tool.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High-resolution CT scan of the paranasal sinuses: Not first-line for adenoids. Indicated more for evaluating chronic sinusitis or anatomical deformities. Also involves unnecessary radiation for a routine case.

 

Option C. Diagnostic nasal endoscopy under general anesthesia: Flexible or rigid nasopharyngoscopy can be done in a cooperative child without anesthesia, making this option unnecessarily invasive as an initial step.

 

Option D. Trial of oral corticosteroids and saline irrigation: Mild symptoms may benefit from decongestants and antihistamines, but corticosteroids are not standard first-line therapy for adenoid hypertrophy. Moreover, this does not provide a diagnostic evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx is the initial investigation of choice for evaluating adenoid hypertrophy and nasopharyngeal airway narrowing in children.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248.

choices.text: Rathke’s pouch represents notochordal attachment to pharyngeal endoderm and can cause Thornwaldt's disease when infected
Nasopharyngeal bursa is a remnant of buccal ectoderm and may give rise to craniopharyngioma
Thornwaldt's cyst arises from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the adenoid mass
Rathke’s pouch lies within the adenoids and connects to the basiocciput through the pharyngeal mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding embryological remnants in the nasopharyngeal region?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thornwaldt's cyst arises from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the adenoid mass 

 

Thornwaldt’s cyst is due to infection of nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant within adenoids

 

The nasopharyngeal bursa is a median epithelial-lined recess found in the adenoid region, representing the site of notochord attachment to the pharyngeal endoderm. Infection of this remnant can lead to Thornwaldt’s cyst or abscess (Thornwaldt’s disease), causing persistent postnasal discharge or crusting.

 

 

Key Concepts:

 

  • Nasopharyngeal bursa:
    • Embryological origin: Site of notochord attachment to pharyngeal endoderm
    • Location: Median epithelial-lined recess within adenoids, extending to basiocciput periosteum
    • Pathology: Infection leads to Thornwaldt’s disease (postnasal discharge, crusting, abscess)
  • Rathke’s pouch:
    • Embryological origin: Buccal ectoderm invagination, gives rise to anterior pituitary
    • Seen clinically as a dimple above adenoids
    • Pathology: May give rise to craniopharyngioma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rathke’s pouch represents notochordal attachment to pharyngeal endoderm and can cause Thornwaldt's disease when infected:  Incorrect – This confuses Rathke’s pouch with the nasopharyngeal bursa; notochordal origin is linked to nasopharyngeal bursa, not Rathke’s pouch

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal bursa is a remnant of buccal ectoderm and may give rise to craniopharyngioma: Incorrect – Craniopharyngiomas arise from Rathke’s pouch, which is from buccal ectoderm, not the nasopharyngeal bursa

 

Option D. Rathke’s pouch lies within the adenoids and connects to the basiocciput through the pharyngeal mucosa: Incorrect – This falsely assigns anatomical characteristics of nasopharyngeal bursa to Rathke’s pouch

 

Educational Objective:
 

Thornwaldt’s cyst arises from infection of the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant located within the adenoid mass.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 241.

choices.text: CT scan with contrast followed by elective drainage
Incision and drainage of abscess without anesthesia with suction ready

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with high fever, difficulty in swallowing, noisy breathing, and neck stiffness. The child holds the neck in extension with torticollis and has a muffled cry. Examination reveals a unilateral bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall. Lateral neck X-ray shows widening of the prevertebral space. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage of abscess without anesthesia with suction ready

 

Gold-standard, especially in children with airway compromise risk

 

The child presents with classical signs of an acute retropharyngeal abscess, which is:

 

  • Common in children <3 years due to the presence of retropharyngeal lymph nodes
  • Unilateral posterior pharyngeal bulge
  • Symptoms of airway obstruction, including stridor, dysphagia, and torticollis
  • Lateral neck radiograph shows widened prevertebral shadow, confirming deep space infection

 

Management:

 

  • Incision and drainage is the treatment of choice
  • It is performed without general anesthesia, as intubation may rupture the abscess and cause aspiration
  • Suction must be immediately available
  • IV antibiotics are started
  • Tracheostomy is indicated if airway obstruction or laryngeal edema is present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency tonsillectomy: Irrelevant. Tonsils are not involved here; this is a retropharyngeal space infection

 

Option B. CT scan with contrast followed by elective drainage: Imaging is useful but in clearly evident clinical cases, immediate drainage is necessary. Delay can risk airway compromise

 

Option D. Trial of oral antibiotics and observation: Not acceptable. This is a deep neck space infection in a child with stridor, risking sudden airway obstruction

 

Educational Objective:


Acute retropharyngeal abscess in young children requires immediate incision and drainage without anesthesia, with suction on standby to prevent aspiration.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

choices.text: Await culture confirmation before initiating antitoxin therapy
Start erythromycin and antitoxin immediately based on clinical suspicion
Give IV steroids and nebulized epinephrine for airway edema
Intubate immediately and refer for surgical debridement of the membrane

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. Examination reveals a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils and soft palate that bleeds on attempted removal. The child has tender cervical lymphadenopathy and early signs of respiratory distress. His neck appears swollen with a "bull-neck" appearance. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start erythromycin and antitoxin immediately based on clinical suspicion

 

This is the gold standard approach in suspected diphtheria

 

  • This child presents with classic signs of faucial diphtheria:
    • Adherent greyish membrane that bleeds on removal
    • Involvement of tonsils and soft palate
    • Low-grade fever, toxic appearance, and "bull-neck" (cervical lymphadenopathy)
    • Airway compromise may develop, especially with laryngeal involvement
  • Management Principles:
    • Do not wait for culture results—start treatment based on clinical suspicion
    • Antitoxin is the mainstay—neutralizes circulating exotoxin
    • Erythromycin or penicillin is used to eliminate C. diphtheriae
    • Test for hypersensitivity before antitoxin (horse serum) administration

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Await culture confirmation before initiating antitoxin therapy: Dangerous. Delay in antitoxin allows exotoxin-mediated complications (myocarditis, paralysis)

 

Option C. Give IV steroids and nebulized epinephrine for airway edema: May help airway symptoms, but do not address underlying bacterial and toxin-related pathology

 

Option D. Intubate immediately and refer for surgical debridement of the membrane: Debridement is contraindicated due to risk of bleeding and worsening airway obstruction

 

Educational Objective:
 

In suspected faucial diphtheria, treatment with antitoxin and antibiotics must be started immediately without waiting for culture confirmation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

choices.text: Acute catarrhal tonsillitis is usually bacterial and begins with formation of a membrane on the tonsil
Acute follicular tonsillitis involves the crypts and presents with yellow spots at the openings of crypts
Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis shows purulent material oozing from the crypts without tonsillar enlargement
Acute membranous tonsillitis is most commonly caused by viral infections in children under 1 year of age

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acute tonsillitis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute follicular tonsillitis involves the crypts and presents with yellow spots at the 

 

  • In acute follicular tonsillitis, the infection spreads into the crypts, and purulent material accumulates.
  • This appears as yellowish spots at the openings of crypts, which is a hallmark sign. penings of crypts

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Acute catarrhal tonsillitis is usually bacterial and begins with formation of a membrane on the tonsil: Incorrect. Acute catarrhal tonsillitis is a superficial inflammation associated with viral infections and generalized pharyngitis, not membrane formation. Membranes form in later stages, like membranous tonsillitis.

 

 

Option C. Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis shows purulent material oozing from the crypts without tonsillar enlargement: Incorrect. In acute parenchymatous tonsillitis, the tonsil tissue itself is involved, resulting in uniform enlargement and redness. Purulent discharge from crypts is more characteristic of follicular type.

 

Option D. Acute membranous tonsillitis is most commonly caused by viral infections in children under 1 year of age: Incorrect.  Acute membranous tonsillitis occurs when exudates coalesce into a membrane, usually after follicular stage. It is not common in infants, and is typically bacterial, not viral in origin.

 

Additional Points from the Content:

 

  • Tonsil Structure: Surface epithelium, crypts (tubular invaginations), and lymphoid tissue
  • Etiology:
    Commonest: β-hemolytic streptococci
     Others: Staphylococci, Pneumococci, H. influenzae
     Often secondary to viral infections
     More common in school-going children, rare in infants and adults >50 years

 

Educational Objective:
 

Acute follicular tonsillitis involves the crypts and presents with yellow spots at their openings due to accumulation of purulent material.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 259

choices.text: Tubal tonsils located near the fossa of Rosenmüller
Palatine tonsils located between the anterior and posterior pillars
Pharyngeal nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a component of Waldeyer’s ring?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Piriform sinus mucosa

 

The piriform sinus does not contain lymphoid tissue and is not a part of Waldeyer’s ring

 

Waldeyer’s ring is a ring of lymphoid tissue located in the subepithelial layer of the pharynx, functioning as the first line of immune defense against inhaled or ingested pathogens. It includes aggregates of lymphoid tissue that form prominent tonsillar structures.

 

The six components of Waldeyer’s ring are:

 

  1. Nasopharyngeal tonsil (adenoids) – on the roof and posterior wall of nasopharynx
  2. Palatine tonsils – between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal arches (tonsillar pillars)
  3. Lingual tonsil – at the base of the tongue
  4. Tubal tonsils – located around the opening of the Eustachian tube in the fossa of Rosenmüller
  5. Lateral pharyngeal bands – along the lateral wall of the pharynx
  6. Nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Tubal tonsils located near the fossa of Rosenmüller: Incorrect.  Tubal tonsils are a documented part of Waldeyer’s ring; located near the fossa of Rosenmüller

 

Option B. Palatine tonsils located between the anterior and posterior pillars: Incorrect. Palatine tonsils are a major visible part of the ring

 

Option C. Pharyngeal nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall: Incorrect. Pharyngeal nodules on the posterior pharyngeal wall are part of the ring

Waldeyer’s ring is a ring of lymphoid tissue in the pharynx including adenoids, palatine, lingual, tubal tonsils, lateral bands, and posterior wall nodules—but not the piriform sinus.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with complaints of persistent postnasal drip, nasal obstruction, recurrent sore throat, and dull occipital headaches for the past few months. He also reports intermittent low-grade fever and fullness in the ears. Otoscopy reveals signs of bilateral serous otitis media. On examination of the nasopharynx, a midline cystic swelling with crusting is seen on the posterior wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thornwaldt’s disease
 

The combination of midline cystic swelling, postnasal drip, crusting, serous otitis media, and dull occipital headache is characteristic.

 

This is a classic presentation of Thornwaldt’s disease, which is infection of the pharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the posterior nasopharyngeal wall. Key clinical features include:

 

  • Persistent postnasal discharge with crusting
  • Midline cystic swelling in nasopharynx
  • Nasal obstruction
  • Eustachian tube dysfunction causing serous otitis media
  • Occipital headache
  • Recurrent sore throat and low-grade fever

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Occurs in adolescent males, but typically presents with profuse epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and a lateral mass arising near the sphenopalatine foramen, not a midline cystic lesion with crusting.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma: Common in adults with unilateral hearing loss, neck mass, nasal obstruction, and epistaxis; typically arises in fossa of Rosenmüller, not midline.

 

Option D. Adenoid hypertrophy with chronic rhinitis: May cause similar symptoms but does not present with a distinct cystic swelling or occipital headache; crusting is more consistent with bursitis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Thornwaldt’s disease is pharyngeal bursitis caused by infection of a notochordal remnant, presenting with postnasal drip, midline nasopharyngeal swelling, and serous otitis media.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

choices.text: Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatoglossus and palatopharyngeus muscles at the level of the oropharynx
Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the second pharyngeal pouch and arises from the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Sphenopalatine foramen opens into the nasopharynx and is formed by the maxilla and vomer bones

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pharyngeal and adjacent anatomical structures is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

The fossa of Rosenmüller is a recess in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, lying posterior to the torus tubarius (the bulge caused by the cartilaginous end of the Eustachian tube), and is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

 

Key anatomical facts from the content:

 

  • Adenoids: Located at the junction of roof and posterior wall of nasopharynx
  • Thornwaldt cyst/nasopharyngeal bursa: Remnant of notochord, arises from the same area as adenoids
  • Torus tubarius: Bulge due to Eustachian tube opening
  • Fossa of Rosenmüller: Posterior to torus tubarius, common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Sphenopalatine foramen: Lies 1 cm posterior to end of middle turbinate, formed by palatine bone (perpendicular plate) and pterygoid part of sphenoid; it opens into pterygopalatine fossa and is the most common site for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)
  • Pterygopalatine fossa: Between maxillary sinus and pterygoid part of sphenoid; connects laterally to infratemporal fossa via pterygomaxillary fissure
  • Passavant’s ridge: Muscular ridge formed by palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor, blocks nasopharynx during swallowing
  • Palatine tonsils: Located in oropharynx between palatoglossus (anterior pillar) and palatopharyngeus (posterior pillar)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatoglossus and palatopharyngeus muscles at the level of the oropharynx: Incorrect – Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor, not by palatoglossus

 

Option B. Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the second pharyngeal pouch and arises from the lateral wall of the nasopharynx: Incorrect – Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the notochord, not the second pharyngeal pouch, and arises from the posterior wall, not lateral wall

 

Option D. Sphenopalatine foramen opens into the nasopharynx and is formed by the maxilla and vomer bones: Incorrect – Sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the perpendicular plate of palatine bone and pterygoid process of sphenoid, not maxilla and vomer, and it opens into the nasal cavity, not nasopharynx

 

Educational Objective:
 

The fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius, is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 254

Horizontal incision 2–3 cm below the angle of mandible under general anesthesia
Interval tonsillectomy after initial conservative antibiotic therapy

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with fever, severe sore throat, trismus, and painful swelling just below the angle of the mandible. Examination shows prolapse of the ipsilateral tonsil and deviation of the uvula, with significant odynophagia. He is unable to open his mouth adequately for oropharyngeal examination. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal incision 2–3 cm below the angle of mandible under general anesthesia

 

This is the standard approach for drainage of parapharyngeal abscess

 

The patient presents with features of an anterior compartment parapharyngeal abscess:

 

  • Trismus → due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsillar prolapse and peritonsillar fullness
  • External swelling below angle of mandible
  • Odynophagia, toxic signs, and inability to open mouth fully

 

Management:

 

  • IV antibiotics should be initiated
  • Surgical drainage is essential
  • Drainage is done by a horizontal skin incision 2–3 cm below the mandible
  • Dissection is carried out bluntly towards the styloid process
  • Transoral drainage is contraindicated due to risk of injury to carotid artery, jugular vein, and cranial nerves

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transoral drainage of the abscess under local anesthesia: Contraindicated due to close proximity of great vessels and cranial nerves in the posterior compartment

 

Option B. Needle aspiration through the tonsillar fossa to decompress the collection: Risky and not effective; this isn’t a peritonsillar abscess

 

Option D. Interval tonsillectomy after initial conservative antibiotic therapy: Used after recurrent peritonsillar abscess, not for deep neck space abscesses

 

Educational Objective:
 

Parapharyngeal abscess is drained by a horizontal external incision below the mandible; transoral drainage is contraindicated due to risk of vascular injury.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 268

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a known diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) presents with nasal obstruction, profuse recurrent epistaxis, and left facial swelling. CT imaging shows extension of the mass into the pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae, without intracranial extension. The patient underwent successful preoperative embolization. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic surgical excision within 24–48 hours of embolization

 

This is the standard approach after embolization, particularly if tumor is accessible via endoscopy.

 

The treatment of choice for JNA is surgical excision, which should be performed within 24–48 hours after embolization to minimize bleeding before collateral blood supply develops. In this case, the tumor has extended laterally (into pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae) without intracranial spread, making it suitable for surgical resection via endoscopic or open approaches depending on accessibility.

 

Key Concepts from the Passage:

 

  • Surgery is the definitive treatment for JNA; various approaches include transpalatine, endoscopic, transmaxillary (Le Fort I), and facial translocation depending on tumor extension.
  • Preoperative embolization reduces bleeding and should be followed by surgical removal within 24–48 hours
  • Radiotherapy is reserved for recurrent, inoperable tumors or those with intracranial extension involving the internal carotid blood supply
  • Hormonal therapy and chemotherapy have limited roles and are used in selected resistant or aggressive recurrent cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start high-dose corticosteroids and observe for regression: Corticosteroids are not effective in JNA; observation is not appropriate due to risk of hemorrhage and progression.

 

Option C. Plan radiotherapy to the nasopharynx to achieve long-term regression: Radiotherapy is not first-line. It is reserved for inoperable, recurrent, or intracranial disease, especially when blood supply is from the internal carotid system.

 

Option D. Initiate androgen-blocking therapy with flutamide to shrink the tumor: Hormonal therapy has limited efficacy and is not used as primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Surgical resection within 24–48 hours after preoperative embolization is the treatment of choice for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma without intracranial extension.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 249

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the ENT clinic with complaints of recurrent sore throat, bad breath, and night-time choking episodes for the past several months. Examination reveals enlarged tonsils meeting at midline, yellowish beads on the tonsillar surface, and flushing of anterior pillars. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are palpable bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schedule for elective tonsillectomy

 

Indicated for chronic tonsillitis with functional impairment or recurrent infections

 

The patient has classical features of chronic tonsillitis:

 

  • Recurrent sore throat
  • Halitosis due to pus in crypts
  • Choking spells at night and thick speech → suggest obstructive hypertrophy
  • On exam:
    Enlarged tonsils meeting at midline → chronic parenchymatous type
    Yellowish beads of pus → chronic follicular type
    Flushing of anterior pillars and jugulodigastric lymphadenopathy → strong indicators of chronic infection
  • According to guidelines, tonsillectomy is indicated when:
     There are recurrent infections interfering with normal function
     Tonsils cause airway obstruction, dysphagia, or speech problems

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance and warm saline gargles: Suitable for mild symptoms, but not in patients with recurrent infections and obstructive features

 

Option B. Start a course of antibiotics for 10 days: May help in acute exacerbations, but this child has chronic signs; surgery is the definitive treatment

 

Option D. Obtain a throat swab for bacterial culture before proceeding: Not necessary for chronic cases with clear clinical features and surgical indication

 

Educational Objective:
 

Tonsillectomy is indicated in chronic tonsillitis with recurrent infections, obstructive symptoms, and significant tonsillar hypertrophy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with fever, difficulty swallowing, neck stiffness, and stridor. Examination reveals a unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. Imaging confirms a deep neck space infection. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the anatomical location and implications of this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is located between buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia, and may spread to the mediastinum

 

This child presents with classical signs of a retropharyngeal abscess:

 

  • Common in young children (due to presence of retropharyngeal lymph nodes, which regress by age 3–4)
  • Causes unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Lies in the retropharyngeal space, located:
    • Anterior to alar fascia
    • Posterior to buccopharyngeal fascia
    • Extends from skull base to the tracheal bifurcation
    • Can spread inferiorly into the mediastinum
  • The space is divided by a midline fibrous raphe into two lateral Gillette’s spaces

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It lies anterior to the vertebral bodies and extends from skull base to coccyx: This describes the prevertebral space, not the retropharyngeal space.

 

Option C. It is separated by a vertical midline raphe into symmetrical prevertebral compartments: The retropharyngeal space is divided by the fibrous raphe, not the prevertebral space.

 

Option D. It usually arises from tuberculosis of the cervical spine and presents with bilateral bulging of the pharynx: This describes a prevertebral abscess secondary to Pott’s spine, not retropharyngeal.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The retropharyngeal space lies between the buccopharyngeal and prevertebral fascia, extends to the tracheal bifurcation, and infections here can spread to the mediastinum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 266

choices.text: Pyriform sinus carcinoma; radiotherapy is preferred even in large tumors with nodal involvement
Pyriform sinus carcinoma; cervical lymph node metastasis is rare and late in disease course
Pyriform sinus carcinoma; laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy with neck dissection is indicated for localized disease
Postcricoid carcinoma; surgical excision is rarely used due to anatomical inaccessibility

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with a foreign body sensation in the throat, pricking pain during swallowing, and referred earache. Examination reveals a fixed neck mass in the upper cervical region, but no hoarseness or obvious mass in the oropharynx. Indirect laryngoscopy shows pooling of secretions in the left pyriform sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which of the following statements is most accurate regarding management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyriform sinus carcinoma; laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy with neck dissection is indicated for localized disease

 

This is standard treatment if confined to pyriform sinus without postcricoid involvement

 

This is a typical case of carcinoma of the pyriform sinus, which is the most common hypopharyngeal malignancy (60%), especially in men >40 years, often presenting late due to:

 

  • Deep location
  • Silent progression
  • Early sign: foreign body sensation, referred otalgia (via CN IX)
  • Fixed cervical lymphadenopathy is often the first clinical sign due to early lymphatic spread

 

Management:

 

  • Early-stage without nodes: Radiotherapy may suffice
  • Locally advanced but confined to pyriform sinus:
    Total laryngectomy + partial pharyngectomy
     Followed by elective/prophylactic neck dissection
    Post-op radiotherapy often given
  • If tumor extends to postcricoid:
    Total laryngopharyngectomy with reconstruction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy for large tumors with nodes: Radiotherapy alone is not sufficient in node-positive or extensive disease; surgery is standard

 

Option B. Cervical nodes rare in pyriform sinus carcinoma: Lymph node metastasis is common and early (75% at presentation)

 

Option D. Postcricoid carcinoma with rare surgery: Surgery is done, often laryngopharyngectomy, despite anatomical difficulty

 

Educational Objective:
 

Pyriform sinus carcinoma commonly presents late with early nodal spread, and localized disease is treated with laryngectomy, partial pharyngectomy, and neck dissection.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 273

choices.text: It lies anterior to the buccopharyngeal fascia and contains the space of Gillette
Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in adults is commonly due to tuberculosis secondary to Pott’s spine
The retropharyngeal space is undivided and contains a single large midline lymph node
Retropharyngeal abscess causes a midline bulge and is best diagnosed by CT scan of the brain

questions.text: Which of the following statements about retropharyngeal space and abscess is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in adults is commonly due to tuberculosis secondary to Pott’s spine


Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in adults is often caused by tubercular infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes, typically due to Pott’s disease (tuberculosis of the spine).

 

The retropharyngeal space is a deep neck space with important anatomical and clinical implications:

 

  • Location: Lies behind the buccopharyngeal fascia
  • It is divided into two halves by a midline fibrous raphe
  • Each half is referred to as space of Gillette, which contains retropharyngeal lymph nodes, also known as nodes of Rouviere
  • Infections here can result in retropharyngeal abscess, presenting with:
    • Bulge just lateral to midline in posterior pharyngeal wall
    • On X-ray, shows increased prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • Acute abscess (common in children): requires immediate drainage
  • Chronic abscess (common in adults): usually tubercular in origin, especially due to Pott’s spine, and treated with antitubercular therapy (ATT)

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It lies anterior to the buccopharyngeal fascia and contains the space of Gillette: Incorrect – The retropharyngeal space lies behind, not anterior to, the buccopharyngeal fascia

 

Option C. The retropharyngeal space is undivided and contains a single large midline lymph node: Incorrect – The space is divided into two halves (not undivided), each containing lymph nodes (not a single midline node)

 

Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess causes a midline bulge and is best diagnosed by CT scan of the brain: Incorrect – The bulge is lateral to midline, and X-ray neck (lateral view) shows increased prevertebral shadow, not CT brain

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess in adults is typically tubercular in origin, secondary to Pott’s spine, and managed with antitubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 247.

questions.text: A 65-year-old post-operative patient develops fever, swelling, and tenderness at the angle of the mandible on the fifth day after abdominal surgery. The swelling is erythematous, indurated, and mildly fluctuant. The patient is dehydrated and toxic. On oral examination, pressure over the swelling leads to pus exuding from the Stenson's duct. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Initiate IV fluids and antibiotics, followed by surgical drainage via a preauricular incision

 

This is the standard treatment.

 

This is a classic presentation of a parotid abscess, typically seen:

 

  • In dehydrated, post-operative or debilitated patients
  • Due to stasis of saliva and retrograde spread of infection via Stenson’s duct
  • Caused most often by Staphylococcus aureus

 

Key findings in this patient:

 

  • Unilateral parotid swelling
  • Pus exuding from Stenson’s duct
  • Toxicity and dehydration
  • Indurated and fluctuant swelling at the angle of mandible

 

Management approach:

 

  • Rehydrate the patient
  • Start empiric IV antibiotics
  • Perform surgical drainage through a preauricular incision (parallel to facial nerve branches) to avoid nerve injury
  • The incision is not sutured tightly, allowing drain placement and healing by secondary intention

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start IV antibiotics and monitor for spontaneous drainage IV antibiotics alone: Inadequate. Antibiotics are essential but drainage is required in frank abscess formation. Fluctuation and pus from duct confirm abscess.

 

Option B. Immediate incision and drainage via a submandibular approach: Incorrect for parotid abscess. This is used for submandibular gland pathologies, not parotid.

 

Option D. Emergency superficial parotidectomy: Too aggressive and not warranted unless there's chronic/recurrent pathology or neoplasm. It also carries high facial nerve injury risk.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Parotid abscess in dehydrated patients requires IV fluids, antibiotics, and surgical drainage via a preauricular incision parallel to the facial nerve branches.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 263

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia and occasional spitting of blood. Examination reveals no intraoral lesions, but a firm, bilateral upper deep cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals a midline exophytic lesion over the posterior pharyngeal wall. What is the most likely diagnosis and best initial step for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior pharyngeal wall carcinoma; proceed with endoscopy and biopsy

 

Essential to confirm diagnosis and assess extent

 

This is a classic case of carcinoma of the posterior pharyngeal wall, which:

 

  • Is the least common hypopharyngeal malignancy (~10%)
  • Occurs mostly in males >50 years
  • Presents with dysphagia, spitting of blood, or bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Tumor is often exophytic, midline, and evident on indirect laryngoscopy
  • Retropharyngeal lymph nodes (not always palpable) and bilateral cervical nodes are commonly involved

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Endoscopy is essential for:
    • Tissue diagnosis (biopsy)
    • Assessment of tumor extent
    • Detection of synchronous primaries

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postcricoid carcinoma; CT & barium swallow:  Incorrect site. This would present with dysphagia alone, often in younger females with iron-deficiency anemia

 

Option C. Laryngeal carcinoma; microlaryngoscopy: Hoarseness is often the first symptom in laryngeal carcinoma. This patient has posterior pharyngeal wall findings

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma; MRI of skull base: NPC presents with nasal symptoms, serous otitis media, and retropharyngeal bulge, not isolated posterior wall lesions

 

Educational Objective:
 

Carcinoma of the posterior pharyngeal wall presents with dysphagia and bilateral cervical nodes and is confirmed by endoscopic biopsy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 275

Plan for CT-guided excision after confirming diagnosis with nasal swab cytology

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent, spontaneous episodes of profuse epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction. His voice has become denasal, and he complains of hearing difficulty. On examination, a purplish lobulated mass is seen filling the nasopharynx and obstructing the choanae. Otoscopy shows a dull tympanic membrane suggestive of middle ear effusion. CT scan of the head reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform carotid angiography with embolization followed by surgical resection
 

Correct and standard of care. Angiography identifies feeders, and embolization of external carotid feeders reduces bleeding. Surgery is ideally performed within 24–48 hours of embolization to avoid revascularization.

 

This patient has classic clinical and radiological findings of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), a vascular tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males.
Key findings:

 

  • Profuse recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction, denasal speech, conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction
  • Nasopharyngeal mass that should not be palpated or biopsied due to risk of severe bleeding
  • CT scan finding of Holman-Miller sign (anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus) is pathognomonic
  • Carotid angiography defines vascular supply (mostly external carotid system) and allows for pre-operative embolization to minimize bleeding

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform endoscopic biopsy of the lesion in the outpatient setting: Dangerous. Biopsy in JNA carries a high risk of life-threatening hemorrhage and should be avoided unless absolutely necessary, and only under controlled conditions with general anesthesia and full setup for bleeding control.

 

Option B. Plan for CT-guided excision after confirming diagnosis with nasal swab cytology:  Nasal swab cytology does not confirm diagnosis, and CT-guided excision without angiographic embolization risks massive intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Start high-dose corticosteroids to reduce the vascularity of the lesion: Steroids are not effective in reducing vascularity of JNA. Management is surgical, preceded by embolization.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is diagnosed clinically and radiologically; biopsy is avoided, and pre-operative carotid angiography with embolization is essential before surgical resection.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasopharynx and neck

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of unilateral nasal obstruction, serous otitis media, and a painless neck swelling. He also reports recent onset of facial pain and diplopia. Nasal endoscopy reveals a submucosal mass in the nasopharynx. Biopsy is planned. Which of the following investigations is most appropriate to assess both the extentof the primary tumor and skull base involvement before treatment planning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasopharynx and neck
 

Provides detailed evaluation of primary site, bone erosion, and neck nodes, making it ideal for staging and planning

 

High-resolution contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for evaluating nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It accurately assesses:

 

  • The primary tumor
  • Bone erosion of the skull base and clivus
  • Parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal extension
  • Cervical lymph node involvement

 

MRI is better for soft tissue spread, while PET-CT is used for detecting distant metastases, not initial local staging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: Useful for evaluating pulmonary metastases, but does not assess local tumor extent or skull base involvement

 

Option C. PET-CT scan: Excellent for detecting distant metastases, but not the first-line imaging for local staging or surgical planning

 

Option D. Pure tone audiogram: Helpful to document serous otitis media and monitor treatment-related ototoxicity, but not for staging the primary tumor

 

Educational Objective:
 

Contrast-enhanced CT of the nasopharynx and neck is the preferred imaging for evaluating the local extent, bony invasion, and nodal status in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 252

choices.text: The mucous membrane of the pharynx is entirely lined by stratified squamous epithelium
The pharyngeal aponeurosis is thickest inferiorly and merges with the esophageal wall
The muscular coat consists of an external layer of constrictors and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles
The buccopharyngeal fascia lies internal to the pharyngeal aponeurosis and lines the mucosal surface

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the structure of the pharyngeal wall is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The muscular coat consists of an external layer of constrictors and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles

 

  • The muscular coat is composed of:
    • External constrictor muscles
    • Internal longitudinal muscles (stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, palatopharyngeus)

 

The pharyngeal wall is composed of four layers from inside out:

 

  1. Mucous membrane
    • Lined by ciliated columnar epithelium in the nasopharynx
    • Stratified squamous epithelium elsewhere
    • Contains numerous mucous glands
  2. Pharyngeal aponeurosis (pharyngobasilar fascia)
    • Fibrous layer beneath mucosa
    • Thick near the base of the skull, thin inferiorly
    • Fills muscle gap at skull base
  3. Muscular coat
    • External layer: 3 constrictors (superior, middle, inferior)
    • Internal layer: 3 longitudinal muscles — stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, palatopharyngeus
  4. Buccopharyngeal fascia
    • Covers external surface of muscular coat
    • Extends to buccinator anteriorly
    • Blends with pharyngeal aponeurosis above superior constrictor

 

 

(a) mucous membrane, (b) pharyngobasilar fascia, (c) muscular coat and (d) buccopharyngeal fascia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The mucous membrane of the pharynx is entirely lined by stratified squamous epithelium: Incorrect – The pharynx has ciliated columnar epithelium in the nasopharynx, and stratified squamous elsewhere — not entirely squamous.

 

Option B. The pharyngeal aponeurosis is thickest inferiorly and merges with the esophageal wall: Incorrect – The pharyngeal aponeurosis is thick superiorly, not inferiorly.

 

Option D. The buccopharyngeal fascia lies internal to the pharyngeal aponeurosis and lines the mucosal surface: Incorrect – The buccopharyngeal fascia lies on the outer surface of the muscle layer, not internal.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The pharyngeal wall has a muscular coat with an external constrictor layer and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles (stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, and palatopharyngeus).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 238

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is diagnosed with a nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The tumor extends into the oropharynx with parapharyngeal space involvement. There is bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, each node measuring less than 6 cm in greatest dimension, and no evidence of distant metastasis. Based on the TNM classification, what is the clinical stage of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage III
 

Stage III includes T1, T2a, T2b, T3 with N2 and M0.

 

According to TNM staging:

 

  • T2b: Tumor involves soft tissues of oropharynx with parapharyngeal extension
  • N2: Bilateral lymph node metastases, ≤6 cm in size, above supraclavicular fossa
  • M0: No distant metastasis

 

Based on the stage grouping:

 

  • T2b N2 M0 → Stage III

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IIB: Incorrect. IIB includes T1–T2a with N1, but T2b with N2 is beyond this stage.

 

Option C. Stage IVA: Incorrect. This includes T4 (involvement of cranial nerves, skull base, orbit, etc.) or any T with N3, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Stage IVB: Incorrect. This is any T with N3, not applicable to this patient who has N2.

 

Educational Objective:
 

T2bN2M0 nasopharyngeal carcinoma (parapharyngeal extension with bilateral nodes <6 cm) is classified as Stage III.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253

choices.text: Proton pump inhibitor therapy with lifestyle modification

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, gurgling sounds on swallowing, foul breath, and occasional regurgitation of undigested food, especially at night. He reports a chronic cough and has lost significant weight over the past few months. A barium swallow reveals a posterior midline outpouching at the level of the pharyngoesophageal junction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision

 

Definitive treatment, especially in fit patients.

 

This patient presents with classic symptoms of a Zenker’s diverticulum (pharyngeal pouch):

 

  • Occurs in elderly patients, typically >60 years
  • Caused by herniation of pharyngeal mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence (between thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus of inferior constrictor)
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysphagia (especially after a few swallows)
    • Gurgling on swallowing
    • Regurgitation of undigested food
    • Chronic cough and aspiration risk
    • May be associated with hiatus hernia
  • Diagnosis: Barium swallow is diagnostic
  • Treatment of choice: Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision

 

In debilitated patients, endoscopic Dohlman’s procedure or CO₂ laser is preferred.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopy and biopsy: Risky; there's a risk of perforating the pouch. Not done as first-line for diagnosis.

 

Option C. PPI and lifestyle modification: Useful in GERD, not pharyngeal pouch.

 

Option D. Feeding jejunostomy with chemotherapy: This would be for malignancy or advanced esophageal cancer, not for a benign diverticulum.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Zenker’s diverticulum presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and gurgling, and is treated by cricopharyngeal myotomy with excision of the pouch.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 275
