Incise the sublingual space via intraoral route under local anesthesia

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the floor of the mouth, difficulty swallowing, and progressive trismus for the past 2 days. He has poor dental hygiene and recently had a painful lower molar. On examination, there is bilateral submandibular swelling, firm, woody induration, and elevation of the tongue. He appears toxic and has stridor. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secure the airway and start IV antibiotics urgently

 

This addresses the most life-threatening aspect—airway compromise—and initiates essential systemic treatment.

 

This is a classic presentation of Ludwig’s angina, which is:

 

  • A rapidly spreading cellulitis of the submandibular space (includes sublingual, submental, and submaxillary spaces)
  • Most commonly arises from dental infections of lower molars
  • Leads to elevation and posterior displacement of the tongue, risking airway 

 

 

Key features from the case and text:

 

  • Trismus, odynophagia, submandibular swelling, tongue elevation → highly suggest Ludwig’s angina
  • Risk of airway compromise is high; laryngeal edema and posterior tongue displacement are critical
  • Initial management includes:
    • Securing airway (endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy if needed)
    • High-dose IV antibiotics (to cover mixed aerobic and anaerobic organisms)
    • Surgical drainage as needed, but airway comes first

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate surgical exploration of submental space: Incision may be needed after airway is secured. Jumping to surgical drainage without addressing airway is dangerous.

 

Option B. Dental consultation and oral antibiotics: This is not a stable outpatient case. Oral antibiotics are insufficient and delay life-saving airway management.

 

Option D. Intraoral drainage of sublingual space: Appropriate only if infection is localized, which is not the case here. This patient has progressed to submandibular and submental space involvement with signs of airway obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Ludwig’s angina is a potentially life-threatening cellulitis of the submandibular space, and securing the airway with IV antibiotics is the first priority in management.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 264

choices.text: Erythromycin for 2 days followed by supportive care
Tonsillectomy in acute setting to relieve symptoms immediately

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of high-grade fever, sore throat, and refusal to eat for the past 2 days. The mother also reports bad breath and occasional abdominal pain. On examination, the child has coated tongue, fetid breath, enlarged congested tonsils with yellow spots on their surface, and tender jugulodigastric lymphadenopathy. A diagnosis of acute follicular tonsillitis is made. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paracetamol and penicillin for 7–10 days

 

This is the standard of care for acute bacterial tonsillitis.

 

  • This child has classical signs of acute follicular tonsillitis:
    • Fever, sore throat, refusal to eat
    • Bad breath (foetid)
    • Abdominal pain (due to mesenteric lymphadenitis, mimicking appendicitis)
    • Tonsillar yellow spots = purulent material in crypts
    • Tender jugulodigastric nodes

 

 

  • Management includes:
    • Analgesics: e.g., Paracetamol to relieve pain and reduce fever
    • Antibiotics: Penicillin is the drug of choice as Streptococcus is the most common pathogen.
    • Alternative: Erythromycin (only for penicillin-allergic patients)
      Hydration and supportive care

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciprofloxacin: Not recommended in children due to risk of cartilage damage; also not first-line for Streptococcal pharyngitis/tonsillitis.

 

Option B. Erythromycin for 2 days followed by supportive care: Duration too short; standard treatment requires 7–10 days to prevent complications like rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Tonsillectomy in acute setting: Not indicated during acute infection unless there are recurrent or obstructive symptoms long-term. Surgery during acute infection increases risk of bleeding and poor healing.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Acute follicular tonsillitis is treated with analgesics and a 7–10 day course of penicillin; erythromycin is used in penicillin-allergic patients.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 259

choices.text: Radical neck dissection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.text: A 48-year-old man diagnosed with stage III nasopharyngeal carcinoma undergoes staging workup showing no distant metastases. The tumor involves the parapharyngeal space with multiple ipsilateral cervical nodes. He is otherwise healthy with good performance status. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Concomitant chemoradiotherapy with cisplatin
 

Standard of care for Stage III NPC, improves both local control and survival outcomes.

 

Stage III and IV nasopharyngeal carcinomas are typically treated with concomitant chemoradiotherapy to improve local control and treat micrometastases. Cisplatin, alone or combined with 5-FU, is commonly used. IMRT is the preferred radiation technique as it minimizes damage to adjacent structures.

 

Key Treatment Concepts:

 

  • Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice in NPC.
    • Stage I & II: Radiotherapy alone
    • Stage III & IV: Concomitant chemoradiotherapy (cisplatin ± 5-FU)
    • IMRT is preferred for precise dose delivery
  • Recurrent/residual disease may require:
    • Second course of radiation (risk of neurotoxicity)
    • Brachytherapy (Gold-198)
    • Nasopharyngectomy (via endoscopy, Le Fort I, swing approach, etc.)
  • Positive nodes in the neck: Require radical neck dissection, but only after ensuring no residual tumor or distant metastases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) alone: IMRT is part of treatment, but not sufficient alone for Stage III disease. Needs concurrent chemotherapy.

 

Option C. Radical neck dissection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy: Neck dissection is used for residual nodal disease, not first-line for Stage III NPC unless nodes persist after CRT.

 

Option D. Endoscopic nasopharyngectomy followed by brachytherapy: Surgery and brachytherapy are reserved for persistent or recurrent tumors, not first-line in newly diagnosed Stage III cases.

 

Educational Objective:


Concomitant chemoradiotherapy with cisplatin is the treatment of choice for stage III and IV nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 252

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric ENT clinic with complaints of persistent mouth breathing, difficulty feeding, and poor weight gain. The mother notes that the child often has a wet, runny nose and tends to speak in a toneless voice. On examination, the child has an elongated face, open mouth posture, pinched-in nose, prominent upper teeth, and a highly arched palate. Tympanic membranes appear retracted bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenoid hypertrophy with eustachian tube obstruction
 

This child presents with classic features of adenoid hypertrophy:

 

Adenoid hypertrophy with eustachian tube obstruction –Best explains all the findings: nasal blockage, ear symptoms, voice changes, adenoid facies, feeding issues, and poor growth.

 

  • Mouth breathing and feeding difficulty due to nasal obstruction
  • Wet bubbly nose from impaired nasal drainage and associated chronic rhinitis
  • Voice change from loss of nasal resonance
  • Adenoid facies: open mouth, elongated face, crowded teeth, pinched-in nose, and high-arched palate
  • Retracted tympanic membranes suggest eustachian tube dysfunction, commonly caused by enlarged adenoids obstructing the tubal opening
  • These findings altogether point to adenoid hypertrophy with secondary ear and nasal symptoms

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital choanal atresia: Typically presents at birth with cyclic cyanosis relieved by crying. Bilateral cases are emergencies in neonates. Does not explain fluctuating hearing loss or adenoid facies in a 5-year-old.

 

Option B. Allergic rhinitis with secondary maxillary sinusitis: May explain nasal discharge, but not mouth breathing, ear findings, or characteristic facial changes. It also lacks feeding difficulty as seen in infants with adenoidal hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Primary ciliary dyskinesia: Can cause chronic rhinosinusitis and otitis media, but would more likely be associated with recurrent lower respiratory infections, situs inversus, or infertility in older age groups. Also doesn’t produce adenoid facies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Adenoid hypertrophy can cause nasal obstruction, recurrent otitis media, hearing loss, and characteristic adenoid facies in children.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 244

choices.text: It arises through Killian’s dehiscence, located between the superior and middle constrictors
It commonly presents with halitosis, gurgling sounds, and right-sided neck swelling
It is most commonly seen in individuals below 40 years of age
It occurs through a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Zenker’s diverticulum is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It occurs through a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor

The diverticulum forms through Killian’s dehiscence, between thyropharyngeus (oblique) and cricopharyngeus (horizontal) fibers of the inferior constrictor

 

Zenker’s diverticulum arises through Killian’s dehiscence, which is located between the oblique fibers of thyropharyngeus and horizontal fibers of cricopharyngeus, both parts of the inferior constrictor.

 

 

 

Figure: Barium swallow showing Zenker’s diverticulum

 

Zenker’s diverticulum (pharyngeal pouch) is a pulsion-type diverticulum that forms due to herniation of pharyngeal mucosa through an anatomically weak area:

 

  • Killian’s dehiscence: Located between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor
  • It is known as the "gateway of tears" due to its tendency to form this pouch
  • Seen commonly in elderly (>60 years)
  • Symptoms include:
    • Dysphagia
    • Halitosis (due to food retention)
    • Gurgling sounds
    • Left-sided neck swelling with Boyce sign (gurgling on palpation)
  • Diagnosis: Barium swallow (shows outpouching)
  • Treatment: Excision of the pouch, or endoscopic techniques like the Dohlman procedure

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It arises through Killian’s dehiscence, located between the superior and middle constrictors: Incorrect – Killian’s dehiscence is located between parts of the inferior constrictor, not between superior and middle constrictors

 

Option B. It commonly presents with halitosis, gurgling sounds, and right-sided neck swelling: Incorrect – Swelling typically occurs on the left side of the neck, not the right

 

Option C. It is most commonly seen in individuals below 40 years of age: Incorrect – It is usually seen in the elderly (>60 years), not under 40

 

Educational Objective:
 

Zenker’s diverticulum arises through Killian’s dehiscence—between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus parts of the inferior constrictor muscle.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 243.

choices.text: It is located between the pharynx and the sternocleidomastoid muscle and extends from the hyoid bone to the clavicle
Pre-styloid compartment lies medial to the tonsil and contains cranial nerves IX to XII
Post-styloid compartment contains the carotid sheath and its contents, and a mass here causes medial bulge behind the posterior pillar
Pre-styloid compartment contains facial nerve and submandibular gland and a mass here causes bulge in anterior triangle of neck

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the parapharyngeal space is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Post-styloid compartment contains the carotid sheath and its contents, and a mass here causes medial bulge behind the posterior pillar
 

The post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space contains internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, cranial nerves IX–XII, and cervical sympathetic trunk. A lesion here pushes the pharynx medially, with bulge behind the posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

Key anatomical highlights:

 

  • Parapharyngeal space (also called pterygomaxillary, pharyngomaxillary, or lateral pharyngeal space)
    • Located on either side of pharynx, between pharyngeal wall and mandible
    • Inverted pyramid shape – extends from skull base to hyoid bone
  • Medial boundary: Constrictor muscles
  • Lateral boundary: Mandible and parotid gland
  • Divided by styloid process and its muscular/ligamentous attachments into:
    Pre-styloid compartment: Contains mandibular nerve branches, maxillary artery, lies lateral to tonsil, and any mass here pushes tonsil medially
    Post-styloid compartment: Contains carotid sheath (ICA, IJV, CN IX–XII, sympathetic trunk), and mass here causes posteromedial bulge behind posterior pillar

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is located between the pharynx and the sternocleidomastoid muscle and extends from the hyoid bone to the clavicle: Incorrect – Parapharyngeal space lies between pharynx and mandible, not sternocleidomastoid; and it extends from skull base to hyoid, not clavicle

 

Option B. Pre-styloid compartment lies medial to the tonsil and contains cranial nerves IX to XII: Incorrect – Pre-styloid lies lateral (not medial) to tonsil and does not contain cranial nerves

 

Option D. Pre-styloid compartment contains facial nerve and submandibular gland and a mass here causes bulge in anterior triangle of neck: Incorrect – Facial nerve and submandibular gland are not contents of pre-styloid parapharyngeal space, and bulge is in oropharynx, not neck

 

Educational Objective:


The post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space contains the carotid sheath and causes a medial pharyngeal bulge behind the posterior tonsillar pillar when involved.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

choices.text: The danger space lies between the buccopharyngeal and prevertebral fascia and extends up to the coccyx
Retropharyngeal space lies behind the alar fascia and contains the danger space
The alar fascia separates the retropharyngeal space from the danger space, which extends inferiorly up to T4
Prevertebral space lies between the alar and buccopharyngeal fasciae and terminates at the mediastinum

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding deep neck spaces and fasciae is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The alar fascia separates the retropharyngeal space from the danger space, which extends inferiorly up to T4
 

The alar fascia lies posterior to the buccopharyngeal fascia and anterior to the prevertebral fascia, dividing the area into:

 

  • Retropharyngeal space (in front of alar fascia)
  • Danger space (behind the alar fascia), which extends down to the T4 vertebral level and can transmit infection from pharynx to mediastinum.

 

Fascial layers and spaces of the neck (from anterior to posterior):

 

  1. Buccopharyngeal fascia
  2. Retropharyngeal space
    • Lies between buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia
  3. Alar fascia
    • Lies between retropharyngeal space and danger space
  4. Danger space (Alar space)
    • Lies between alar fascia and prevertebral fascia
    • Extends from skull base to T4 level
    • Called "danger space" due to its potential to transmit infection to the mediastinum
  5. Prevertebral fascia
  6. Prevertebral space
    • Lies behind prevertebral fascia, extends down to coccyx
    • Infections here can cause midline bulge
  7. Vertebral column lies posterior to this setup

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The danger space lies between the buccopharyngeal and prevertebral fascia and extends up to the coccyx: Incorrect – Danger space lies between alar and prevertebral fascia, not buccopharyngeal and prevertebral; and it ends at T4, not coccyx

 

Option B. Retropharyngeal space lies behind the alar fascia and contains the danger space: Incorrect – Retropharyngeal space lies in front of alar fascia, not behind it

 

Option D. Prevertebral space lies between the alar and buccopharyngeal fasciae and terminates at the mediastinum: Incorrect – Prevertebral space lies behind the prevertebral fascia and extends to the coccyx, not to the mediastinum

 

Educational Objective:
 

The alar fascia separates the retropharyngeal space from the danger space, which extends from skull base to T4 and can spread infection to the mediastinum.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248.

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels
Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels
Eustachian tube and levator veli palatini muscle

questions.text: Which of the following structures pass through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels


The internal laryngeal nerve (branch of superior laryngeal nerve) and superior laryngeal vessels pass through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles.

 

 

The pharynx is a fibromuscular tube extending from the base of the skull to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It has gaps between the constrictor muscles that transmit key neurovascular structures:

 

  1. Gap between skull base and superior constrictor (Sinus of Morgagni)
     • Contains: Eustachian tube, tensor veli palatini, levator veli palatini, ascending palatine artery
  2. Gap between superior and middle constrictors
     • Contains: Stylopharyngeus muscle, glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
  3. Gap between middle and inferior constrictors
     • Contains: Internal laryngeal nerve, superior laryngeal vessels
  4. Gap between inferior constrictor and oesophagus
     • Contains: Recurrent laryngeal nerve, inferior laryngeal vessels

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect:  Stylopharyngeus and glossopharyngeal nerve pass through the gap between superior and middle constrictors

 

Option B. Recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels: Incorrect:  Recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels pass below inferior constrictor, near the esophagus

 

Option D. Eustachian tube and levator veli palatini muscle: Incorrect: Eustachian tube and levatorveli palatini pass through the sinus of Morgagni (gap above superior constrictor)

 

Educational Objective:
 

The internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels pass through the gap between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 239.

choices.text: IV antibiotics and emergency incision and drainage
Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild dysphagia, posterior throat discomfort, and a gradually enlarging midline swelling on the posterior pharyngeal wall. He also has multiple cervical lymph nodes and a history of weight loss and low-grade fever. Cervical spine X-ray reveals destruction of C3 and C4 vertebral bodies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

 

This is the standard treatment for tubercular prevertebral abscesses.

 

This is a classic presentation of a chronic retropharyngeal abscess (specifically a prevertebral abscess) due to tuberculosis:

 

  • Most commonly caused by cervical spine tuberculosis (Pott’s disease)
  • Abscess lies behind the prevertebral fascia, usually midline
  • Often has minimal symptoms like mild dysphagia and throat discomfort
  • Cervical spine X-ray is diagnostic (shows vertebral destruction)
  • May be associated with tuberculous cervical lymphadenopathy

 

Management:

 

  • Incision and drainage via:
    • Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (for low abscesses)
    • Posterior border (for high abscesses)
  • Full course of ATT (antitubercular therapy) is essential to prevent recurrence and control infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV antibiotics and emergency drainage: Suitable for acute pyogenic abscess, not tubercular. Also, ATT is essential.

 

Option C. Oral steroids and observation: Steroids may worsen TB if given alone; definitive drainage and ATT are necessary.

 

Option D. Immediate tracheostomy: Airway obstruction is not typical in chronic prevertebral TB abscess. Tracheostomy is reserved for acute airway compromise, e.g., in Ludwig’s angina or acute retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess due to cervical spine tuberculosis is treated with incision and drainage followed by a full course of antitubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a foreign body sensation in the throat and halitosis. On examination, a gritty mass is felt on probing the tonsil. There is no fever, dysphagia, or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonsillolith

 

  • A tonsillolith is a calcified concretion that forms within a blocked crypt of the tonsil in chronic tonsillitis.
  • Composed of inorganic salts (e.g., calcium and magnesium) and debris, it may gradually enlarge and erode through the tonsil.
  • Presents with:
    • Foreign body sensation
    • Halitosis
    • Gritty feel on probing
  • More common in adults, and diagnosis is often clinical. Treatment includes simple removal or tonsillectomy if deeply seated or recurrent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar cyst:  Appears as a yellowish swelling, usually painless and symptomless, caused by blocked crypt, but lacks gritty sensation. Easily drained if needed.

 

 

Option C. Intratonsillar abscess: Presents with severe local pain, dysphagia, fever, and a swollen red tonsil. Caused by pus accumulation within tonsil tissue. Requires antibiotics and drainage.

 

 

Option D. Peritonsillar abscess: More severe, with trismus, muffled voice, uvular deviation, and marked systemic symptoms. Not consistent with this case's presentation.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Tonsilloliths present with halitosis and a foreign body sensation and are diagnosed by a gritty feel on probing the tonsil.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 261

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with low-grade fever and a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils and soft palate. The membrane is adherent and bleeds on attempted removal. There is mild sore throat, and urine analysis reveals albuminuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diphtheria

 

Fits all described features: slow onset, mild pain, adherent membrane, bleeding on removal, soft palate involvement, and albuminuria.

 

  • Diphtheria is classically characterized by:
    • Slow onset and mild local symptoms
    • A dirty grey adherent membrane that extends beyond the tonsils to the soft palate
    • Bleeds on removal
    • Albuminuria (due to systemic toxin effects)
    • Diagnosis confirmed by throat swab showing Corynebacterium diphtheriae

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute membranous tonsillitis:  This may appear similar but the membrane is limited to the tonsils, forms from coalesced exudates in acute follicular tonsillitis, and can usually be removed without bleeding.

 

 

Option C. Vincent angina: Usually unilateral, less fever, and membrane is removable, revealing an irregular ulcer. Fusiform bacilli and spirochetes are seen on Gram stain.

 

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis:  Typically seen in young adults, with bilaterally enlarged tonsils, prominent lymphadenopathy (especially posterior triangle), and splenomegaly. Paul–Bunnell test is positive.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Diphtheria presents with an adherent, dirty grey membrane over the tonsils and soft palate that bleeds on removal and is confirmed by detection of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and diplopia. Imaging reveals a mass in the nasopharynx with extension into the orbit and skull base. Clinical examination shows bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, each node less than 6 cm, with no distant metastasis. What is the correct clinical stage of this patient’s nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage IVA

 

Defined as T4 with N0, N1, or N2, M0

 

Let’s break this down using the TNM classification:

 

  • T4: Tumor with intracranial extension, orbital involvement, and skull base erosion qualifies as T4
  • N2: Bilateral cervical nodes, ≤6 cm, and above supraclavicular fossa fits N2
  • M0: No distant metastasis

 

Putting this together:
 

T4 N2 M0 → Stage IVA

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage III: Includes T1–T3 with N2 or T2b with N2, but not T4

 

Option C. Stage IVB: Requires any T with N3, not present here

 

Option D) Stage IVC: Requires M1 (distant metastases), which is not the case

 

Educational Objective:
 

T4N2M0 nasopharyngeal carcinoma is classified as Stage IVA due to intracranial and orbital involvement with bilateral lymph node metastasis and no distant spread.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with progressive left-sided hearing loss and a painless neck lump just below the angle of the mandible. He also reports intermittent nasal obstruction and occasional epistaxis. Otoscopy reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane. Neurological examination reveals decreased corneal reflex on the left and mild weakness of left lateral gaze. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
 

Fits all symptoms: adult with unilateral middle ear effusion, nasal obstruction, neck mass, cranial nerve involvement (CN V and VI).

 

This patient presents with classic features of NPC, including:

 

  • Unilateral serous otitis media in an adult (suggestive of eustachian tube obstruction)
  • Nasal obstruction and epistaxis
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy near the angle of the mandible
  • Cranial nerve involvement: CN V (decreased corneal reflex), CN VI (lateral rectus palsy causing diplopia)

 

These signs and symptoms are typical of NPC with skull base extension, which may involve cranial nerves V, VI, and cause Trotter’s triad (conductive hearing loss, facial pain, palatal paralysis). Cervical node metastasis is the most common presentation, occurring in up to 90% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma: While this can cause hearing loss and retracted TM, it does not explain the neck mass, epistaxis, nasal symptoms, or cranial nerve palsies.

 

Option B. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Seen in adolescent males, not a 35-year-old adult. Also presents with profuse epistaxis, not cranial neuropathies or lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Glomus jugulare tumor: Can cause lower cranial nerve palsies (IX–XI) and pulsatile tinnitus, but nasal symptoms and lymphadenopathy are not typical. Also, it's located in the jugular foramen, not nasopharynx.

 

Educational Objective:


Nasopharyngeal carcinoma commonly presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, unilateral serous otitis media, nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and cranial nerve palsies due to skull base extension.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 251

choices.text: Carcinoma of the upper esophagus; associated with Barrett's esophagus
Carcinoma of the pyriform sinus; associated with heavy smoking and alcohol use
Carcinoma of the postcricoid region; associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome
Carcinoma of the larynx; associated with vocal abuse and laryngopharyngeal reflux

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and a history of iron-deficiency anemia. She has no significant smoking or alcohol history. Indirect laryngoscopy does not reveal any mass, but pooling of secretions is noted in the hypopharynx. Barium swallow reveals an irregular narrowing in the postcricoid region. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is an important associated risk factor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoma of the postcricoid region; associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome

 

Iron-deficiency anemia (microcytic hypochromic), female predilection, dysphagia—all point to this

 

This is a classic presentation of postcricoid carcinoma, which:

 

  • Constitutes ~30% of hypopharyngeal malignancies
  • More common in females, sometimes in their 3rd–4th decades
  • Strongly associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome (iron-deficiency anemia, dysphagia, esophageal webs)
  • Presents with:
    • Progressive dysphagia
    • Weight loss
    • Possible aphonia or voice changes if recurrent laryngeal nerve is involved

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • May be missed on indirect laryngoscopy
  • Look for:
    • Loss of laryngeal crepitus
    • Pooling of secretions
    • Edema of postcricoid region
  • Confirmed by:
    • Barium swallow
    • Endoscopy with biopsy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma of upper esophagus + Barrett’s: Barrett’s esophagus is associated with adenocarcinoma of the lower esophagus, not upper or postcricoid

 

Option B. Pyriform sinus carcinoma:  Associated with smoking/alcohol, neck nodes common; less likely in young, non-smoking females

 

Option D. Carcinoma of larynx + vocal abuse: Vocal abuse predisposes to benign vocal cord lesions, not postcricoid carcinoma

 

Educational Objective:
 

Carcinoma of the postcricoid region is strongly associated with Plummer–Vinson syndrome and presents with progressive dysphagia, especially in young females.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 274

choices.text: Investigation of dysphagia due to cancer esophagus

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to rigid oesophagoscopy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical spine tuberculosis

 

Rigid oesophagoscopy is useful both diagnostically and therapeutically:

 

Diagnostic Indications:

 

  • Dysphagia evaluation (e.g. carcinoma, achalasia, stricture)
  • Retrosternal burning (e.g. reflux, hiatus hernia)
  • Hematemesis (e.g. varices)
  • Work-up in secondaries neck with unknown primary (panendoscopy)

 

Therapeutic Indications:

 

  • Foreign body removal
  • Dilatation in strictures/achalasia
  • Benign lesion excision
  • Insertion of palliative tubes (e.g. Souttar’s tube)
  • Variceal injection

 

Contraindications:

 

  • Trismus – limits mouth opening
  • Cervical spine disease – TB, trauma, osteophytes, spondylosis, kyphosis
  • Receding mandible – makes access difficult
  • Aortic aneurysm – risk of rupture
  • Advanced systemic illness – relative contraindication

 

For such cases, flexible fibreoptic oesophagoscopy is preferred.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Removal of esophageal foreign body: Indicated for foreign body removal (Therapeutic)

 

Option B. Investigation of dysphagia due to cancer esophagus: Indicated to evaluate dysphagia (Diagnostic)

 

Option D. Injection sclerotherapy for esophageal varices: Used for variceal injections (Therapeutic)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigid oesophagoscopy is indicated in diagnostic and therapeutic esophageal conditions, but is contraindicated in trismus, cervical spine disease, receding mandible, aortic aneurysm, and severe systemic illness.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition,

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoes rigid oesophagoscopy. One hour later, he complains of severe interscapular pain and develops subcutaneous emphysema. What is the most likely complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perforation of the esophagus at Killian’s dehiscence

 

Common complications of rigid oesophagoscopy include:

 

Mechanical Injuries:

 

  • Lips, teeth, arytenoids, and pharyngeal mucosa — due to careless technique.

 

Major Complication – Esophageal Perforation:

 

 

  • Occurs due to forceful insertion.
  • Symptoms: interscapular pain, surgical emphysema within 1 hour.
  • Can lead to retropharyngeal or mediastinal abscess.

 

Tracheal Compression:

 

  • Scope compresses posterior tracheal wall → especially in children.
  • Causes respiratory obstruction and cyanosis → managed by immediate withdrawal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retropharyngeal abscess: Retropharyngeal abscess may occur later as a complication of perforation, but not the earliest sign.

 

Option B. Arytenoid dislocation: Arytenoid injury is possible but would present with hoarseness, not emphysema.

 

Open D. Tracheal compression causes cyanosis, not subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perforation at Killian’s dehiscence is the most serious complication of rigid oesophagoscopy, presenting with surgical emphysema and interscapular pain.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 427

Flexible fibreoptic oesophagoscopy is a preferred outpatient procedure that provides magnified view of oesophagus, stomach, and duodenum, and is ideal in cases with spine or jaw abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered an absolute indication for tonsillectomy in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recurrent febrile seizures due to tonsillitis

 

Absolute Indications of Tonsillectomy include:

 

  • Recurrent throat infections:
    • ≥7 episodes/year in the past year
    • ≥5/year for 2 years
    • ≥3/year for 3 years
    • OR ≥2 weeks of missed school/work in 1 year
  • Peritonsillar abscess:
    • In children → tonsillectomy after 4–6 weeks
    • In adults → after second episode, becomes absolute
  • Tonsillitis causing febrile seizures → Absolute
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing:
    • Airway obstruction (sleep apnoea)
    • Difficulty swallowing
    • Speech interference
  • Suspicion of malignancy (e.g., unilaterally enlarged tonsil)

 

Relative Indications:

 

  • Diphtheria or streptococcal carriers
  • Chronic halitosis due to chronic tonsillitis
  • Recurrent streptococcal tonsillitis in valvular heart disease patients

 

As Part of Another Procedure:

 

  • Palatopharyngoplasty, Glossopharyngeal neurectomy, Styloidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic halitosis unresponsive to treatment: Chronic halitosis → Relative indication, not absolute

 

Option B. First episode of peritonsillar abscess: First peritonsillar abscess → Not absolute; second is

 

Option D. Streptococcal carrier state without symptoms: Streptococcal carrier → Also relative indication

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonsillitis causing recurrent febrile seizures is an absolute indication for tonsillectomy in children.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 428

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to performing a tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Haemoglobin of 8.5 g%

 

Tonsillectomy Contraindications include:

 

  1. Haemoglobin <10 g% → Increased risk of perioperative complications
  2. Acute upper respiratory infection, including acute tonsillitis → Increased risk of bleeding
  3. Age <3 years → Poor surgical risk
  4. Cleft palate (overt or submucous) → Worsens speech post-surgery
  5. Bleeding disorders (e.g., hemophilia, purpura, leukemia)
  6. During polio epidemics → Post-op viral dissemination risk
  7. Uncontrolled systemic diseases: diabetes, HTN, cardiac issues
  8. Menstrual period → Avoided due to increased bleeding tendency

 

Incorrect Options:

 

  • A. Recurrent acute tonsillitis is a common indication, not a contraindication.
  • C. 5 years is a safe age for surgery; <3 years is the risk age.
  • D. Streptococcal carrier is a relative indication, not a contraindication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haemoglobin <10 g% is a contraindication to tonsillectomy due to increased risk of perioperative complications.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 428

choices.text: Supine with neck hyperextended and no support
Supine with head extended and a pillow under shoulders

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the position used during tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supine with head extended and a pillow under shoulders

 

  • The Rose's position is the standard position for tonsillectomy.

 

 

  • In this position:
    • Patient lies supine.
    • Pillow is placed under the shoulders to allow gentle extension of the head and neck.
    • A rubber ring under the head provides stabilization.
    • Hyperextension must be avoided to prevent airway and spinal complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trendelenburg position with head flexed forward: Trendelenburg is not used for ENT surgeries like tonsillectomy.

 

Option B. Supine with neck hyperextended and no support: Hyperextension is contraindicated.

 

Option D. Lateral decubitus with neck flexed: Lateral decubitus is used in certain GI or pulmonary procedures, not tonsillectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rose’s position (supine with head extended and shoulder support) is the standard position for tonsillectomy to provide optimal surgical exposure and airway safety.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 428

choices.text: Patient should be kept in coma position until recovery from anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a recommended component of postoperative care after tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ibuprofen is preferred for analgesia to reduce pain and inflammation

 

Ibuprofen and aspirin are avoided post-tonsillectomy because they impair platelet function and increase bleeding risk. Paracetamol is the preferred analgesic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient should be kept in coma position until recovery from anesthesia: Coma position (lateral side-lying) prevents aspiration until full recovery from anesthesia.

 

Option B. Ice cream and cold milk can be given after full recovery: Cold liquids like milk and ice cream are soothing and permitted after recovery.

 

Option D. Salt water or Condy’s gargles are advised 3–4 times daily: Gargles with Condy’s solution or salt water help maintain oral hygiene and reduce infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-tonsillectomy care includes coma position, cold fluids, paracetamol for pain, salt water gargles, and avoidance of NSAIDs like aspirin and ibuprofen to prevent bleeding.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 429

questions.text: Which of the following tonsillectomy techniques is considered a cold technique that uses ultrasound to simultaneously cut and coagulate tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Harmonic scalpel

 

It is a cold method that uses ultrasound energy to cut and coagulate simultaneously, resulting in less tissue damage and reduced postoperative pain compared to electrocautery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrocautery: Incorrect. Though it reduces blood loss, it is a hot technique and causes thermal injury to tissues.

 

Option C. Laser tonsillotomy: Incorrect. This uses laser energy (KTP-512 or CO₂), and is not a cold technique. It is used especially in patients unfit for general anesthesia to reduce tonsillar mass.

 

Option D. Guillotine method: Incorrect. An older, largely abandoned technique, suitable only in mobile tonsils without scarring; not a cold method and lacks precision.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Harmonic scalpel tonsillectomy is a cold technique that uses ultrasound to cut and coagulate tissue with minimal damage and pain.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 430

choices.text: Reactionary hemorrhage due to dislodgement of clot
Primary hemorrhage due to surgical vessel injury
Bleeding due to injury to lingual artery

questions.text: A 6-year-old child underwent tonsillectomy under general anesthesia. Within a few hours postoperatively, he begins to bleed from the mouth. Examination reveals a clot at the tonsillar fossa. Which of the following best explains the reason for this bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reactionary hemorrhage due to dislodgement of clot

 

Reactionary hemorrhage happens within 24 hours of surgery. The presence of a clot can impair the clipping effect of superior constrictor muscles on the vessels. Clot removal and application of pressure or vasoconstrictors are initial management steps. This fits the scenario described.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A: Secondary hemorrhage occurs after 7–10 days, usually due to infection of the healing tonsillar bed. Not the case here as bleeding occurred within 24 hours.

 

Option C. Primary hemorrhage occurs during surgery due to direct injury to a vessel, not several hours later.

 

Option D. Lingual artery lies below the level of the tonsillar bed and is not commonly injured during tonsillectomy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Reactionary hemorrhage after tonsillectomy occurs within 24 hours due to clot formation that impairs vessel compression by the superior constrictor muscle.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 430

choices.text: Secondary hemorrhage due to sepsis and slough separation

questions.text: A 7-year-old child, who underwent tonsillectomy 6 days ago, presents with sudden onset of blood-stained sputum followed by moderate bleeding from the mouth. Examination reveals a friable tonsillar fossa with signs of local infection. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary hemorrhage due to sepsis and slough separation

 

Secondary hemorrhage typically occurs between the 5th and 10th postoperative day. It results from infection (sepsis) and premature separation of the slough from the tonsillar bed. It may begin with blood-tinged sputum and can become profuse. Management includes topical adrenaline, pressure, and in severe cases, electrocoagulation or even external carotid artery ligation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Primary hemorrhage occurs during or immediately after surgery, not on day 6.

 

Option B. Reactionary hemorrhage typically occurs within 24 hours, usually due to increased BP or clot dislodgement.

 

Option D. Hypertrophy of lingual tonsil is a late and compensatory complication, not an acute hemorrhagic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary hemorrhage after tonsillectomy occurs between 5–10 days post-op due to infection and slough separation from the tonsillar bed.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 430

choices.text: To treat adenoid hypertrophy causing sleep apnoea
To correct speech delay due to hearing loss

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with chronic mouth breathing, nasal speech, and frequent snoring at night. On examination, there is evidence of adenoid hypertrophy. The child is also undergoing evaluation for dental malocclusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate indication for adenoidectomy in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To treat adenoid hypertrophy causing sleep apnoea

 

Adenoid hypertrophy leading to mouth breathing, snoring, speech abnormality (rhinolalia clausa), or sleep apnoea syndrome is a primary indication for adenoidectomy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. To correct dental malocclusion: Incorrect. Adenoidectomy does not correct dental malocclusion, but it prevents recurrence after orthodontic correction. So it is not the primary indication.

 

Option B. To reduce risk of velopharyngeal insufficiency: Incorrect. In fact, cleft palate or submucous palate is a contraindication to adenoidectomy, as it may worsen velopharyngeal insufficiency.

 

Option D. To correct speech delay due to hearing loss: Incorrect. While chronic otitis media with effusion is an indication, speech delay alone without documented hearing loss is not an indication. Also, hearing loss must be due to adenoid-associated effusion for adenoidectomy to be indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy is indicated in children with adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, sleep apnoea, rhinolalia clausa, or recurrent otitis media.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 431

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a recognized complication of adenoidectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mandibular fracture

 

Not a complication of adenoidectomy. It is not mentioned as a known risk; injury to eustachian tube, pharyngeal muscles, and vertebrae may occur, but not to the mandible.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Grisel syndrome: True complication. It refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation following ENT surgery like adenoidectomy. It presents as neck pain and torticollis. Special care must be taken in Down syndrome due to atlantoaxial instability.

 

Option B. Velopharyngeal insufficiency: True complication. Seen if adenoids are removed in the presence of an unrecognized submucous cleft palate, leading to nasal regurgitation and hypernasal speech.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal stenosis:  True complication. Rare but occurs due to scarring after excessive trauma during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy may result in complications such as hemorrhage, Grisel syndrome, velopharyngeal insufficiency, injury to eustachian tube or vertebrae, and nasopharyngeal stenosis, but not mandibular fracture.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 432

questions.text: The instrument shown is most appropriately used in which of the following surgeries?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tonsillectomy

 

  • Boyle-Davis Mouth Gag is an instrument designed to:
    • Keep the mouth open and
    • Retract the tongue anteriorly
    • It has interchangeable tongue blades suited for various age groups.
  • It is used in:
    • Tonsillectomy
    • Adenoidectomy
    • Soft palate surgeries
    • Palatoplasty
    • Nasopharyngeal surgeries (e.g., excision of angiofibroma)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microlaryngeal surgery – Requires a suspension laryngoscope, not a Boyle-Davis gag.

 

Option B. Caldwell-Luc operation – Involves the maxillary sinus via canine fossa; Boyle-Davis is not used.

 

Option D. Direct laryngoscopy – Performed using a direct laryngoscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boyle-Davis mouth gag is used to open the mouth and retract the tongue in procedures like tonsillectomy, adenoidectomy, and palatal surgeries.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 456

choices.text: Tongue surgery without retraction of the tongue

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is most appropriately used in which of the following scenarios?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tongue surgery without retraction of the tongue

 

  • Doyen’s Mouth Gag:
    • Used to keep the mouth open during intraoral surgeries.
    • It does not retract the tongue.
    • Commonly used in tongue surgeries or when tongue retraction is not desirable.
    • Placed on one side over the molar teeth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Tonsillectomy requiring anterior tongue retraction: Tonsillectomy. Requires Boyle-Davis mouth gag which also retracts the tongue.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy with palatal elevation: Adenoidectomy. Usually uses Boyle-Davis gag with separate palate retractors.

 

Option D. Suspension laryngoscopy under general anesthesia: Suspension laryngoscopy. Needs a suspension laryngoscope, not a gag.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doyen’s mouth gag is used in tongue surgeries when mouth opening is needed but tongue retraction is not required.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 456

choices.text: Palate or oral cavity surgery requiring central mouth opening

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is typically used in which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palate or oral cavity surgery requiring central mouth opening

 

  • Jenning’s Mouth Gag:
    • It is used to keep the mouth open by applying it centrally.
    • Helps in oral cavity and palate surgeries.
    • Unlike Doyen’s gag, it provides central retraction and better exposure of the oral cavity.
    • Commonly used in procedures where midline access is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suspension laryngoscopy: Requires a suspension laryngoscope.

 

Option B. Endoscopic nasal surgery: Does not require a mouth gag.

 

Option D. Esophagoscopy through nose: Uses a flexible fibrescope; no gag required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jenning’s mouth gag is centrally applied and used to keep the mouth open during palate and oral cavity surgeries.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 456

Keep the mouth open during tongue surgeries

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is primarily used to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suspend the tongue blade of Boyle-Davis mouth gag

 

 

  • Draffin’s Bipod:
    • Comprises two rods, each with four circular rings.
    • Used during tonsillectomy and oral/pharyngeal surgeries.
    • Each bipod is adjustable, and when mounted into Magauran’s plate, it allows the Boyle-Davis mouth gag to be suspended in a fixed and stable position.
    • This hands-free setup improves surgical exposure and surgeon convenience.

Option A. Retract the nasal septum during septoplasty: Not related to nasal surgeries.

 

Option C. Keep the mouth open during tongue surgeries: That’s Doyen’s or Jenning’s mouth gag.

 

Option D. Dilate the esophagus in achalasia cardia: Esophageal dilators (bougies) are used for achalasia, not this.

Draffin’s bipods are adjustable supports used to suspend the tongue blade of Boyle-Davis mouth gag during oral and oropharyngeal surgeries.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 456

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below and its primary use:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denis Browne’s forceps – holding the tonsil during tonsillectomy

 

  • The instrument shown is Tonsil Holding Forceps (Denis Browne’s):
    • It has a long, curved handle and broad oval fenestrated tips.
    • Specifically designed to hold the tonsil firmly during tonsillectomy, especially when using the dissection method.
    • Allows good traction for precise dissection from the tonsillar fossa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luc’s forceps – removal of nasal polyps: Luc’s forceps – used in nasal surgeries like polypectomy.

 

 

Option B. Allis forceps – retraction of skin: Allis forceps. Traumatic; used for fascia/skin flaps, not tonsils.

 

 

Option D. Lane’s tissue forceps – grasping soft tissue in thyroid surgery: Lane’s tissue forceps – broader use in general surgery but not for tonsil holding.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Denis Browne’s tonsil holding forceps are used to grasp and stabilize the tonsil during tonsillectomy using the dissection method.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 457

choices.text: Waugh’s forceps – tonsillar mucosal incision and dissection
Lane’s tissue forceps – general soft tissue retraction

questions.solution:
Ans. A) Waugh’s forceps – tonsillar mucosal incision and dissection

 

  • The instrument shown is Waugh’s Tonsil Dissection Forceps:
    • It has a slender, toothed tip and serrated handle for firm grip.
    • Specifically used to make initial mucosal incisions and perform blunt dissection of the tonsil from its bed during tonsillectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adson’s forceps – grasping skin edges: Adson’s forceps – smaller, used in plastic surgeries for skin edges.

 

 

Option C. Luc’s forceps – removing nasal polyps: Luc’s forceps – cup-shaped, used for nasal polyps.

 

 

Option D. Lane’s forceps – more general-purpose; not specific for tonsillar surgery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Waugh’s tonsil dissection forceps are used to incise the mucosa and dissect the tonsil from its bed during tonsillectomy.

choices.text: Yankauer suction tube – oral and oropharyngeal suction

questions.text: The instrument shown below is commonly used in ENT surgeries. Identify it and its main use:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yankauer suction tube – oral and oropharyngeal suction

 

  • The image depicts a Yankauer suction tube:
    • Characteristic bulbous tip with side holes.
    • Designed to prevent damage to soft tissues while ensuring effective suction.
    • Used during tonsillectomy, adenoidectomy, and oropharyngeal surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frazier suction cannula – fine suction tip used in neurosurgery and ENT (ear surgeries).

 

 

Option C. Poole suction tube: Has multiple holes for suction in abdominal surgeries.

 

 

Option D. Rosen suction tube: Used for precise suction in middle ear surgeries.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Yankauer suction tube is a wide-bore suction device used for clearing blood and secretions during oral and oropharyngeal surgeries like tonsillectomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 457

questions.text: The instrument shown below is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor

 

  • This is a dual-ended instrument:
    • One end: Blunt dissector used to separate tonsil from its bed during dissection tonsillectomy.
    • Other end: Hooked or flared retractor used to retract the anterior pillar to inspect for residual bleeding.
  • Commonly used in the dissection method of tonsillectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waugh’s forceps: Toothed forceps used for grasping during dissection.

 

 

Option B. Mollison’s dissector: Has a dual-ended blunt and sharp dissector, not a retractor.

 

Option C. Yankauer suction: Used for suction, not dissection or retraction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonsil dissector and anterior pillar retractor is a dual-purpose ENT instrument used in tonsillectomy to dissect the tonsil and expose the fossa for bleeding control.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 457

choices.text: Grasping and applying ligature to bleeding vessel

questions.text: The instruments shown are used primarily during which step of tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grasping and applying ligature to bleeding vessel

 

  • These are tonsil artery forceps:
    • Straight forceps: To clamp bleeding points.
    • Curved forceps: Replaces the straight one to allow space for tying with a ligature.
  • Essential during hemostasis phase of tonsillectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dissection: Done using Waugh’s forceps or a dissector.

 

 

Option B. Opening the mouth: Requires Boyle-Davis or Doyen’s mouth gag.

 

 

Option D. Suction of pooled blood: Suction. Performed with a Yankauer suction cannula.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonsil artery forceps (straight and curved) are used to clamp and ligate bleeding vessels during tonsillectomy for effective hemostasis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 457

questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negus artery forceps – Used as replacement forceps during ligation of bleeding point

 

  • The image shows Negus artery forceps, which has a sharply curved tip.
  • Its unique curvature allows it to replace the primary (straight) forceps clamping a bleeding vessel in the tonsillar fossa.
  • A ligature is then passed around the curved forceps to achieve secure hemostasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waugh’s dissection forceps – Used to dissect tonsil from bed: Waugh’s forceps is a toothed forceps used for dissection.

 

 

Option B. Yankauer suction – Used for suction during tonsillectomy: Yankauer suction is a curved suction cannula.

 

 

Option D. Tonsil snare – Used to crush and cut the lower pole of the tonsil: Tonsil snare is used to crush and cut the lower pole of the tonsil—not to control bleeding.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negus artery forceps are used during tonsillectomy to replace the primary forceps holding a bleeding vessel, enabling easier ligation.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 457

choices.text: Crushing and cutting the lower pole of tonsil
Ligation of bleeding vessels in the tonsillar bed

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is primarily used during tonsillectomy for which of the following purposes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligation of bleeding vessels in the tonsillar bed

 

  • The instrument shown is a Negus Knot Tier.
  • It is used after the bleeding vessel is clamped with an artery forceps.
  • The knot tier carries the ligature knot up to the tip of the forceps to allow precise and secure ligation.
  • Especially useful when the bleeding point is deep and difficult to access.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crushing and cutting the lower pole of tonsil: Refers to tonsil snare.

 

 

Option C. Retracting anterior pillar to inspect fossa: Describes function of anterior pillar retractor.

 

 

Option D. Suctioning pooled blood and secretions: Refers to Yankauer suction tube.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Negus knot tier is used to tie a ligature around a bleeding vessel clamped with artery forceps during tonsillectomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 458

choices.text: To crush and cut the lower pole pedicle of the tonsil

questions.text: The instrument shown is used during tonsillectomy for which of the following purposes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To crush and cut the lower pole pedicle of the tonsil

 

  • The instrument shown is Eve’s Tonsil Snare.
  • It is used after the tonsil is dissected up to the lower pole.
  • The snare loop is passed around the pedicle and then tightened.
  • It crushes and cuts the lower pole, which stimulates vasoconstriction, thereby minimizing bleeding.
  • The wire used is typically No. 25 SWG (Standard Wire Gauge).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To hold the tonsil during dissection: Refers to tonsil holding forceps (e.g., Denis Browne’s)

 

 

Option B. To ligate the bleeding vessels: Refers to tonsil artery forceps or Negus artery forceps

 

 

Option D. To retract the anterior pillar: Refers to anterior pillar retractor

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eve’s tonsil snare is used in tonsillectomy to crush and cut the lower pole pedicle, minimizing bleeding.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 458

choices.text: Eve’s tonsil snare – to crush tonsillar pedicle
Negus artery forceps – to ligate tonsillar vessels

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is shown and what is its primary use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Peritonsillar abscess forceps – to drain quinsy

 

  • The image shows Peritonsillar Abscess Forceps, also known as Quinsy forceps.
  • It has a pointed tip to pierce the abscess and blades that can be opened to dilate the cavity, facilitating pus drainage.
  • The condition treated is peritonsillar abscess (quinsy).
  • Currently, a No. 11 surgical blade with micropore plaster covering (leaving only the tip exposed) is more commonly used due to better control and reduced trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eve’s tonsil snare – to crush tonsillar pedicle: Eve’s snare is used to cut and crush tonsillar pedicle in tonsillectomy.

 

 

Option C. Waugh’s forceps – to dissect tonsillar bed: Waugh’s forceps is a dissection forceps with teeth, used during tonsil removal.

 

 

Option D. Negus artery forceps – to ligate tonsillar vessels: Negus forceps is used to clamp and ligate bleeding vessels, especially in tonsillar fossa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peritonsillar abscess forceps are used to incise and drain a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy), though now often replaced by a No. 11 blade.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 458

questions.text: The instrument shown is used in which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy – removal of adenoids

 

  • The instrument shown is St. Clair Thompson’s adenoid curette with guard.
  • It is specifically designed for adenoid removal.
  • The sharp curette scrapes the adenoid tissue from the nasopharynx.
  • The guard prevents tissue from slipping off and ensures en bloc removal.
  • This is a blind procedure, traditionally done under general anesthesia in Rose’s position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillectomy – dissection of tonsil: Tonsil dissection uses Waugh’s forceps, tonsil snare, and dissectors—not this instrument.

 

Option C. Septoplasty uses mucoperichondrial elevators like Freer’s or Killian’s.

 

Option D. Tracheostomy involves tracheal dilators and hooks—not adenoid curettes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

St. Clair Thompson’s adenoid curette with guard is used for en bloc removal of adenoids during adenoidectomy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 458

questions.text: The instrument shown below is primarily used for which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Guillotine tonsillectomy

 

  • The instrument is Leighton Tonsillotome (Guillotine).
  • It is designed for guillotine tonsillectomy, a rapid method where the tonsil is pulled into the loop and removed in one swift motion.
  • The loop (guillotine) cuts the tonsil at its pedicle.
  • Although faster, this method has a higher chance of incomplete removal and postoperative bleeding compared to dissection tonsillectomy.
  • It is rarely used in modern practice, mainly of historical importance or in mass school-based programs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dissection tonsillectomy: Dissection tonsillectomy uses Waugh’s forceps, tonsil dissector, and snare.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy: Adenoidectomy uses adenoid curettes like St. Clair Thompson’s.

 

Option D. Peritonsillar abscess drainage: Peritonsillar abscess drainage is done using No. 11 blade or abscess forceps, not a guillotine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leighton’s tonsillotome (guillotine) is used for guillotine tonsillectomy by amputating the tonsil in one stroke.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 459
