questions.text: Which of the following anatomical sites is most commonly associated with foreign body impaction in the esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) At the pharyngo-esophageal junction (C6, 15 cm)

 

 

  • The pharyngo-esophageal junction (C6) is the first physiological narrowing and the most common site for foreign body lodgment, especially in children.
  • The other two constrictions are:
    • At 25 cm (T3-T4–T5): arch of aorta and left bronchus.
    • At 40 cm (T10): diaphragmatic hiatus.

 

Table: Normal Constrictions of the Esophagus

 

 

  • Clinical Relevance: Foreign bodies, strictures, and carcinomas are most commonly lodged or seen at these constriction points.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The three normal constrictions of the esophagus are at 15 cm (C6), 25 cm (T3-T4–T5), and 40 cm (T10) from the upper incisors.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 340

choices.text: Entire esophagus is made of smooth muscle
Middle third of esophagus contains only striated muscle
Lower circular fibers of esophagus form the cardiac sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following combinations regarding the muscular layer of the esophagus is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower circular fibers of esophagus form the cardiac sphincter

 

Circular fibers at the lower end thicken to form the cardiac (lower esophageal) sphincter.

 

 

Option A. Entire esophagus is made of smooth muscle: Incorrect – Only the lower third is smooth muscle; upper third is striated; middle is mixed.

 

Option B. Middle third of esophagus contains only striated muscle: Incorrect – Middle third has both striated and smooth muscle.

 

Option D. Esophagus lacks a submucosal layer: Incorrect – Submucosa is present and connects mucosa to the muscle layer.

 

Table: Histological Layers of the Esophagus (from inner to outer)

 

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The esophageal wall has four layers: mucosa, submucosa, muscularis (with both striated and smooth muscle), and outer fibrous layer.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 340

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism preventing gastroesophageal reflux?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricopharyngeal sphincter tone

 

Cricopharyngeal sphincter prevents entry of air/swallowing-related reflux, not gastric reflux.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negative intrathoracic pressure:  Negative pressure aids sphincter closure.

 

Option B. Pinch-cock action of diaphragm: Diaphragmatic sling acts as a pinch-cock.

 

Option D. Mucosal folds at gastroesophageal junction: Mucosal folds also contribute to mechanical barrier function.

 

Table: Phases of Swallowing and Key Events

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

The lower esophageal sphincter and surrounding anatomical and physiological factors prevent reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 341

questions.text: A patient develops severe chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema following forceful vomiting. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal air. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Boerhaave syndrome

 

Spontaneous transmural esophageal rupture, classic after vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss tear: Mallory-Weiss = Mucosal tear, not full-thickness rupture, no mediastinal air.

 

Option C. Esophageal variceal rupture: Esophageal varices cause GI bleeding, not air leaks.

 

Option D. Acute mediastinitis: Mediastinitis is a complication, not the primary diagnosis.

 

Table: Perforation of the Esophagus

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Boerhaave syndrome is a full-thickness esophageal rupture following vomiting, presenting with mediastinal emphysema and chest pain.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 342

choices.text: Acid ingestion is more dangerous than alkali as it penetrates deeper into esophageal layers
The most reliable early investigation is endoscopy beyond all strictures to assess full extent
The pathological process begins with granulation followed by necrosis and stricture formation
Alkaline substances cause deeper penetration and can lead to full-thickness necrosis of esophagus

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of accidentally ingesting a cleaning agent at home. The child now presents with drooling, stridor, and oral ulcerations. On examination, there are signs of airway compromise, perioral burns, and tenderness in the neck. Chest X-ray shows widening of the mediastinum. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alkaline substances cause deeper penetration and can lead to full-thickness necrosis of esophagus

 

Alkaline corrosives, such as lye, are more damaging than acids because they saponify fats and penetrate deep into tissues, often causing sloughing of esophagus and stomach, which can be fatal due to mediastinitis and peritonitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acid ingestion is more dangerous than alkali as it penetrates deeper into esophageal layers. Incorrect: Acids cause coagulative necrosis which limits deeper penetration. Alkalis are more dangerous because they cause liquefactive necrosis, allowing deeper tissue destruction and full-thickness esophageal injury.

 

Option B. The most reliable early investigation is endoscopy beyond all strictures to assess full extent. Incorrect. While early esophagoscopy (within 48 hours) is useful to assess severity, it is contraindicated to pass the scope beyond the first circumferential burn, as this may worsen the injury.

 

Option C. The pathological process begins with granulation followed by necrosis and stricture formation: Incorrect


The pathological stages occur in the correct order as:


1. Acute necrosis,
2. Granulation,
3. Stricture formation (starting ~2 weeks),
not granulation first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaline corrosives cause deep, full-thickness esophageal necrosis and are more dangerous than acids in pediatric accidental ingestion.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 342

choices.text: Immediately perform esophagoscopy and attempt neutralization regardless of timing
Withhold all oral intake, begin IV fluids, airway protection, antibiotics, and consider early esophagoscopy within 48 hours
Perform esophageal dilatation on day 2 to prevent stricture formation
Delay treatment with steroids until strictures begin to appear radiologically

questions.text: A 25-year-old female attempts suicide by ingesting a toilet cleaner (strong alkali) and is brought to the emergency room 3 hours later. She is tachycardic, in mild shock, and has oral ulcers and drooling. What is the most appropriate stepwise approach in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Withhold all oral intake, begin IV fluids, airway protection, antibiotics, and consider early esophagoscopy within 48 hours

 

Withhold all oral intake, begin IV fluids, airway protection, antibiotics, and consider early esophagoscopy within 48 hours: 

 

This outlines the correct, stepwise approach:

 

  • Hospitalize and monitor vitals
    • Manage shock and electrolyte imbalance
    • Provide airway support if needed (e.g., tracheostomy)
    • Start IV antibiotics for 3–6 weeks
    • Insert nasogastric tube for feeding and lumen patency
    • Early esophagoscopy within 48 hours can assess damage
    • Start steroids within 48–96 hours to prevent strictures
    • Follow up with serial imaging and endoscopy every 2 weeks

 

Other options: 

 

Option A. Immediately perform esophagoscopy and attempt neutralization regardless of timing: Incorrect. Neutralization may be considered only if done within 6 hours. After this period, it is not effective and may worsen tissue damage. Esophagoscopy should be done early but carefully and not beyond the first severe circumferential burn.

 

Option C. Perform esophageal dilatation on day 2 to prevent stricture formation: Incorrect: Esophageal dilatation is not done acutely. It is indicated later if strictures form, and only when they are permeable.

 

Option D. Delay treatment with steroids until strictures begin to appear radiologically: Incorrect. Steroids must be initiated early—within 48–96 hours—not after stricture formation. They help reduce fibrosis and prevent stricture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early management of corrosive esophageal burns involves hospitalization, airway support, IV fluids and antibiotics, early esophagoscopy, and timely initiation of steroids.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 342

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with progressive dysphagia 6 weeks after accidental ingestion of household bleach. Barium swallow reveals a long segment esophageal stricture. Esophagoscopy reveals that the stricture is non-negotiable. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plan esophageal reconstruction or bypass

 

  • Plan esophageal reconstruction or bypass – Correct. In non-dilatable strictures, the only definitive solution is surgical — esophageal bypass or reconstruction using stomach or colon segments. This restores continuity and swallowing function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat esophagoscopy after 1 week: Incorrect. Once a stricture is confirmed to be non-dilatable, repeating esophagoscopy does not change the management. The stricture is often fibrotic and cannot be negotiated.

 

Option B. Attempt prograde dilatation via esophagoscope: Incorrect. This is done only if the stricture is permeable, i.e., a guidewire or scope can pass through it.

 

Option C. Perform retrograde dilatation via gastrostomy: Incorrect. Retrograde (from stomach upwards) dilatation is reserved for impermeable strictures—those that can’t be negotiated from above but have a residual lumen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strictures from corrosive esophageal burns that are non-dilatable require esophageal reconstruction or bypass as definitive treatment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 343

choices.text: Prograde dilatation under direct vision via oesophagoscope

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia, initially to solids and later to liquids. He reports a history of accidental ingestion of a bathroom cleaning agent two months ago. He is now malnourished and occasionally regurgitates food. A barium swallow shows a stricture in the lower third of the esophagus. Oesophagoscopy rules out malignancy. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prograde dilatation under direct vision via oesophagoscope

 

Correct. The most appropriate initial treatment for benign esophageal strictures, especially post-corrosive, is prograde dilatation using bougies under direct visualization through an oesophagoscope. This approach is safe and effective and may require multiple sessions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blind bougie dilatation at bedside: Unsafe method. Blind dilatation increases the risk of esophageal perforation and is not recommended.

 

Option C. Surgical excision of the stricture immediately: Not the first-line treatment. Surgery with gastric/colonic reconstruction is reserved for cases where repeated dilatation fails or in non-dilatable strictures.

 

Option D. Start conservative management with corticosteroids alone: Steroids alone are not the definitive treatment. Mechanical dilatation is required to restore luminal patency and improve nutrition.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Benign esophageal strictures are commonly due to corrosive burns and present with progressive dysphagia; prograde dilatation under endoscopic guidance is the initial treatment of choice.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 343

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of heartburn and occasional vomiting. He has a history of chronic cough and obesity. A barium swallow reveals upward displacement of the stomach in line with the esophagus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sliding hiatus hernia

 

In sliding hernia, the stomach is pushed into the thoracic cavity in line with the esophagus, often due to raised intra-abdominal pressure from factors like obesity or coughing. It is common in patients over 40 years. The most frequent complaint is reflux oesophagitis, which may lead to ulceration, stenosis, or haematemesis. Diagnosis is confirmed via barium swallow.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Paraesophageal hernia: Incorrect. In this type, the gastroesophageal junction remains below the diaphragm, and reflux oesophagitis is not seen. It may present with dyspnea on exertion or bleeding due to the stomach occupying the thoracic cavity beside the esophagus.

 

Option B. Achalasia cardia: Incorrect. Achalasia is a motility disorder involving failure of lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, presenting with dysphagia and bird-beak appearance on barium swallow—not upward displacement of the stomach.

 

 

Option D. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST): Incorrect. GISTs are tumors that arise from the GI tract wall and typically present as a mass or bleeding, not herniation of stomach into the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Sliding hiatus hernia is the commonest type of diaphragmatic hernia in elderly, caused by raised intra-abdominal pressure and diagnosed by barium swallow; reflux symptoms dominate and are managed conservatively or surgically.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 343

choices.text: Oral/parenteral iron supplementation with esophageal web dilatation
Surgical excision of the web with neck dissection

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia and fatigue. On examination, she has glossitis, angular stomatitis, and spoon-shaped nails. Blood tests reveal iron-deficiency anemia. A barium swallow shows a web in the postcricoid region. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral/parenteral iron supplementation with esophageal web dilatation

 

Oral/parenteral iron supplementation with esophageal web dilatation
Correct. The patient has classic signs of Plummer–Vinson syndrome, which includes iron-deficiency anemia, dysphagia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, and koilonychia, seen predominantly in females >40 years. Management includes iron supplementation (oral or parenteral, depending on severity) and dilatation of the postcricoid web using bougies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start proton pump inhibitors and observe: Incorrect. PPIs are useful in acid-related disorders like GERD, but not in iron-deficiency dysphagia caused by a mucosal web.

 

Option C. Surgical excision of the web with neck dissection: Incorrect. Surgery is not the first line. Webs can be treated effectively with dilatation. Neck dissection is irrelevant unless carcinoma is confirmed.

 

Option D. Total parenteral nutrition followed by esophagectomy: Incorrect. This aggressive approach is unnecessary. Most cases respond well to conservative therapy and dilatation unless malignancy develops.

 

Educational Objective:


Plummer–Vinson syndrome presents with dysphagia and iron-deficiency anemia in middle-aged women; treatment includes iron supplementation and esophageal web dilatation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 343

choices.text: Start proton pump inhibitors for presumed GERD
Reassure the patient and explain the functional nature of the symptom

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a persistent sensation of a lump in her throat for the past few weeks. She denies difficulty swallowing food or liquids. The symptom is more noticeable between meals and tends to lessen while eating. She is anxious and fears she might have throat cancer. Examination of her pharynx, larynx, and base of tongue is completely normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reassure the patient and explain the functional nature of the symptom

 

Reassure the patient and explain the functional nature of the symptom
Correct. This is a classic presentation of Globus pharyngeus, a functional (non-organic) disorder where the patient feels a lump in the throat without true dysphagia. It is often associated with anxiety or fear of cancer, especially in middle-aged individuals. The sensation is more marked between meals, and examination findings are normal. The best management is reassurance, once organic causes are ruled out.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Start proton pump inhibitors for presumed GERD: Incorrect. Although GERD can sometimes present with throat symptoms, the absence of associated reflux symptoms and the clear features of a functional disorder make PPI therapy unnecessary here.

 

Option B. Refer for immediate endoscopic biopsy: Incorrect. There are no suspicious findings on examination, and the symptom pattern suggests a benign, non-structural cause. Biopsy is not indicated without abnormal findings.

 

Option D. Start empirical antibiotics for possible pharyngitis: Incorrect. There are no signs of infection such as sore throat, fever, or erythema. Antibiotics are not needed.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Globus pharyngeus is a functional sensation of a lump in the throat, typically occurring between meals, with no true dysphagia or abnormal findings; reassurance is the mainstay of treatment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 343

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia. Manometry shows high-amplitude peristaltic contractions in the esophageal body with normal sphincter relaxation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nutcracker esophagus

 

Correct. This is a hypermotility disorder of the esophageal body, characterized by excessively strong peristaltic contractions on manometry. It commonly presents with chest pain and dysphagia but with normal lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. It is one of the classic hypermotility disorders, along with diffuse esophageal spasm and cricopharyngeal spasm.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Achalasia cardia: Incorrect. This is a hypomotility disorder involving impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and absent peristalsis, not high-amplitude contractions. It leads to progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids.

 

 

Option C. Scleroderma: Incorrect. Scleroderma causes hypomotility of the esophageal body and incompetent LES, often resulting in gastroesophageal reflux. Manometry typically shows low-pressure peristalsis and low LES pressure.

 

Option D. Cricopharyngeal achalasia: Incorrect. This involves dysfunction of the upper esophageal sphincter, not the esophageal body. It may cause oropharyngeal dysphagia, especially in the elderly.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a recent history of cerebrovascular accident presents with difficulty initiating swallowing. He complains that food gets stuck at the level of the throat, especially with solids. A videofluoroscopic swallowing study suggests impaired relaxation of the upper esophageal sphincter during swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricopharyngeal spasm

 

Correct. This condition results from failure of the upper esophageal sphincter (UES) to relax properly, often due to incoordination between pharyngeal contraction and UES relaxation. It leads to oropharyngeal dysphagia and is commonly associated with neurological conditions such as cerebrovascular accidents, Parkinson’s disease, bulbar polio, multiple sclerosis, and muscular dystrophies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achalasia cardia: Incorrect. Achalasia affects the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and esophageal body. It causes progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids but does not involve UES dysfunction.

 

 

Option C. Nutcracker esophagus: Incorrect. This is a hypermotility disorder of the esophageal body with high-amplitude peristaltic contractions. It does not involve the UES and typically causes chest pain and dysphagia.

 

 

Option D. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): Incorrect. GERD is caused by LES incompetence, leading to acid reflux and heartburn. It is not primarily associated with dysphagia due to UES dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:


Cricopharyngeal spasm is due to failure of upper esophageal sphincter relaxation during swallowing and commonly follows neurological disorders like stroke or Parkinson’s disease.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 344

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with intermittent retrosternal chest pain and dysphagia. She reports that the pain is unrelated to exertion and sometimes mimics angina. A barium swallow shows a corkscrew appearance of the esophagus. Manometry reveals strong, non-peristaltic contractions of the esophageal body with normal sphincter relaxation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse esophageal spasm

 

Correct. This condition presents with strong, non-peristaltic contractions of the esophageal body, while lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation remains normal. Symptoms include dysphagia, odynophagia, and substernal chest pain that can mimic angina. On barium swallow, it may show a corkscrew or rosary bead appearance. Manometry is diagnostic. Treatment includes dilatation, and severe cases may need myotomy from the arch of aorta to the LES.

 

 

Option A. Achalasia cardia: Incorrect. Achalasia involves absent peristalsis and failure of LES to relax, unlike diffuse spasm which has normal LES relaxation.

 

 

Option B. Nutcracker esophagus: Incorrect. Nutcracker esophagus also shows high-amplitude contractions, but they are peristaltic, not non-peristaltic, and it typically lacks the corkscrew appearance.

 

 

Option D. Cricopharyngeal spasm: Incorrect. This affects the upper esophageal sphincter, causing oropharyngeal dysphagia, not chest pain or corkscrew esophagus.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Diffuse esophageal spasm presents with non-peristaltic strong contractions and chest pain; barium may show corkscrew esophagus, and treatment involves dilatation or myotomy in severe cases.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 344

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with intermittent dysphagia and retrosternal chest pain not related to exertion. His ECG and cardiac workup are normal. Manometry shows strong, high-amplitude, peristaltic contractions of the esophageal body with normal relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nutcracker esophagus

 

Correct. This condition is characterized by strong, high-amplitude peristaltic contractions of the esophageal body. Unlike diffuse esophageal spasm, the contractions remain peristaltic, not disorganized. It presents with dysphagia and substernal chest pain, often mimicking cardiac pain, though the cardiac workup is normal.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Incorrect. Although it also presents with chest pain and dysphagia, in diffuse spasm, the esophageal contractions are non-peristaltic, often producing a corkscrew appearance on barium swallow.

 

 

Option C. Achalasia cardia: Incorrect. In achalasia, there is absent peristalsis and failure of LES to relax, leading to progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids.

 

 

Option D. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): Incorrect. GERD causes heartburn and regurgitation due to LES incompetence, not due to high-amplitude peristaltic contractions. It doesn’t typically cause chest pain mimicking angina with normal peristalsis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Nutcracker esophagus presents with dysphagia and chest pain due to high-amplitude but peristaltic esophageal contractions, distinguishing it from diffuse esophageal spasm.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 344

choices.text: Increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter
Decreased function of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with complaints of retrosternal burning, especially after meals and when lying down at night. He admits to frequent alcohol intake, smoking, and use of calcium-channel blockers for hypertension. What is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased function of the lower esophageal sphincter

 

Correct. Gastro-oesophageal reflux (GERD) is primarily caused by a weakened lower esophageal sphincter (LES), which allows regurgitation of acidic gastric contents into the esophagus. This results in substernal pain, heartburn, and regurgitation, especially after meals or in recumbency. Risk factors include smoking, alcohol, caffeine, pregnancy, hiatus hernia, and drugs like calcium-channel blockers and anticholinergics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter:Incorrect. Increased LES tone would prevent reflux. GERD is due to decreased LES tone.

 

Option B. Spasm of the upper esophageal sphincter: Incorrect. This causes issues like cricopharyngeal spasm with oropharyngeal dysphagia, not reflux-related symptoms.

 

Option D. Gastric outlet obstruction: Incorrect. This may cause vomiting of undigested food, abdominal distension, and early satiety, but not heartburn or retrosternal regurgitation typical of GERD.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Gastroesophageal reflux is caused by decreased lower esophageal sphincter tone, presenting with heartburn and regurgitation, and is managed by lifestyle changes, acid suppression, and sometimes antireflux surgery.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 344

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with long-standing heartburn presents with hoarseness of voice, frequent throat clearing, and chronic cough. He also complains of a sensation of lump in the throat. Laryn goscopic examination shows thickening of posterior laryngeal mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastroesophageal reflux disease

 

Correct. GERD can lead to multiple extra-esophageal complications, including posterior laryngitis, pachydermia laryngis (thickened posterior laryngeal mucosa), contact ulcers, posterior glottic stenosis, and even laryngeal carcinoma. The sensation of a lump in the throat (globus hystericus), hoarseness, chronic throat clearing, and chronic cough are typical laryngopharyngeal manifestations of GERD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord polyp: Incorrect. Polyps usually present with hoarseness but do not cause throat clearing, globus sensation, or posterior laryngeal thickening. They are not associated with reflux.

 

 

Option C. Reinke's edema: Incorrect. This presents with low-pitched hoarseness due to fluid-filled swelling of the vocal cords, primarily in smokers. It does not cause throat clearing or globus.

 

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Incorrect. While it may cause throat irritation or cough, it doesn't result in pachydermia, contact ulcers, or posterior glottic stenosis, which are classic GERD-related laryngeal complications.

 

Educational Objective:
 

GERD can cause esophageal, pulmonary, laryngeal, ear, and throat complications including posterior laryngitis, Barrett’s esophagus, asthma, otitis media, and globus sensation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 344

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with dysphagia that began before the appearance of any skin changes. She also complains of heartburn and occasional regurgitation. Barium swallow reveals absence of peristalsis in the distal two-thirds of the esophagus. What is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scleroderma

 

Correct. Scleroderma is a systemic collagen vascular disorder that affects the smooth muscle of the distal two-thirds of the esophagus and lowers LES tone. This results in absent peristalsis, dysphagia, and reflux oesophagitis, sometimes even strictures due to chronic inflammation. Notably, dysphagia may precede skin manifestations, and hiatus hernia is often associated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achalasia cardia: Incorrect. Achalasia is a primary motility disorder with failure of LES to relax and absent peristalsis, but LES tone is increased, unlike in scleroderma where it is weakened.

 

 

Option B. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Incorrect. This condition features non-peristaltic, high-amplitude contractions with normal LES relaxation—different from the low-pressure, non-contractile esophagus in scleroderma.

 

 

Option D. Nutcracker esophagus: Incorrect. Nutcracker esophagus has strong, high-amplitude peristaltic waves, not absent peristalsis as seen in scleroderma.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Scleroderma causes smooth muscle weakening of the distal esophagus and LES, leading to dysphagia, reflux, and possible stricture formation, often before cutaneous signs appear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 344

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent dysphagia, especially for solid foods. He reports occasional episodes where food feels stuck in his chest, requiring him to regurgitate or drink water. Barium swallow shows a thin, circumferential narrowing at the lower end of the esophagus near the squamocolumnar junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schatzki’s ring

 

Correct. Schatzki’s ring is a thin, mucosal ring seen at the squamocolumnar junction (lower end of esophagus), also called the lower esophageal ring. It typically occurs in patients above 50 years and presents with intermittent dysphagia, especially for solids. Some patients may experience bolus obstruction. It is often associated with a hiatus hernia, and the treatment is esophageal dilatation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achalasia cardia: Incorrect. Achalasia presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids, and is due to failure of LES relaxation. It does not show a thin ring or cause bolus impaction.

 

 

Option C. Esophageal carcinoma: Incorrect. Cancer usually causes progressive dysphagia and systemic symptoms like weight loss. Schatzki’s ring causes intermittent, non-progressive symptoms and occurs at a specific location.

 

 

Option D. Cricopharyngeal spasm: Incorrect. Cricopharyngeal spasm affects the upper esophageal sphincter, not the lower end. It causes difficulty initiating swallowing, not bolus obstruction in the chest.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Schatzki’s ring is a mucosal ring at the lower esophagus causing intermittent dysphagia or bolus obstruction in older adults and is treated by esophageal dilatation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 344

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia. Barium swallow reveals a smooth, ovoid filling defect in the esophageal wall. Endoscopy shows a submucosal swelling without mucosal ulceration. The mass is suspected to arise from the esophageal wall. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enucleation of the tumor via thoracotomy

 

Correct. The most common benign tumor of the esophagus is leiomyoma, accounting for two-thirds of all benign neoplasms. It arises from smooth muscle and presents as a submucosal mass on endoscopy and an ovoid filling defect on barium swallow. Biopsy is avoided due to the risk of mucosal perforation. The recommended treatment is surgical enucleation via thoracotomy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Endoscopic biopsy followed by excision: Incorrect. Biopsy is contraindicated in suspected leiomyoma as it increases the risk of mucosal perforation and complicates future surgery.

 

Option C. Endoscopic snaring and removal: Incorrect. Though some benign tumors like mucosal polyps, lipomas, or fibromas may appear pedunculated, endoscopic removal is avoided due to the risk of perforation. Surgical excision via oesophagotomy is preferred.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy followed by chemotherapy: Incorrect. This is used for malignant tumors, not for benign lesions like leiomyoma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Leiomyoma is the most common benign esophageal tumor; biopsy is avoided and treatment is surgical enucleation via thoracotomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 345

choices.text: Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of esophageal cancer
Radiotherapy is preferred for lower third esophageal cancer
Dysphagia may progress to involve liquids as tumor advances

questions.text: A 62-year-old male chronic smoker and tobacco chewer presents with progressive dysphagia, initially to solids and later to liquids. He has lost significant weight and complains of substernal discomfort and back pain. Barium swallow shows irregular narrowing of the esophageal lumen without proximal dilatation. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dysphagia may progress to involve liquids as tumor advances

 

Correct. Progressive dysphagia, first to solids, then to liquids, is a hallmark of esophageal carcinoma. This progression reflects increasing luminal obstruction as the tumor enlarges and infiltrates the wall.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Adenocarcinoma is the most common type of esophageal cancer: Incorrect. Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for 93% of esophageal cancers, especially in the middle third and in association with smoking, alcohol, tobacco chewing, and Plummer–Vinson syndrome. Adenocarcinoma (3%) is seen in the lower third and may represent an extension of gastric carcinoma.

 

Option B. Flexible oesophagoscopy requires general anesthesia: Incorrect. Flexible fibreoptic oesophagoscopy does not require general anesthesia and provides a magnified view for evaluating the lesion and taking biopsy.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy is preferred for lower third esophageal cancer: Incorrect. Surgery is the preferred treatment for lower third esophageal carcinoma, involving resection of the tumor with margins and primary reconstruction. Radiotherapy is generally used for upper two-thirds where surgery is difficult.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Esophageal cancer typically presents with progressive dysphagia; squamous cell carcinoma is most 

common, and surgery is preferred for lower-third lesions, while radiotherapy is favored for upper esophageal tumors.

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 345

choices.text: Oesophageal dysphagia due to lower esophageal stricture
Preoesophageal dysphagia due to oral phase defect
Preoesophageal dysphagia due to pharyngeal phase paralysis
Oesophageal dysphagia due to diffuse esophageal spasm

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing solids and liquids. He has a history of cerebrovascular accident and reports nasal regurgitation during swallowing. On examination, there is soft palate paralysis. What is the most likely type and phase of dysphagia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preoesophageal dysphagia due to pharyngeal phase paralysis


Correct. Dysphagia with nasal regurgitation following a cerebrovascular accident and soft palate paralysis suggests a problem in the pharyngeal phase of deglutition, which is part of preoesophageal dysphagia. Paralytic conditions such as bulbar palsy, diphtheria, or stroke can impair soft palate closure, leading to nasal regurgitation, and laryngeal dysfunction may lead to aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophageal dysphagia due to lower esophageal stricture: Incorrect. Oesophageal causes typically present with mechanical obstruction or motility disorders and require investigation. There is no nasal regurgitation or neurological deficit.

 

Option B. Preoesophageal dysphagia due to oral phase defect: Incorrect. Oral phase issues involve problems like trismus, xerostomia, or tongue paralysis affecting bolus formation and propulsion—not regurgitation into the nose.

 

Option D. Oesophageal dysphagia due to diffuse esophageal spasm: Incorrect. Diffuse esophageal spasm causes substernal pain and intermittent dysphagia, not nasal regurgitation or signs of cranial nerve dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Preoesophageal dysphagia involves oral or pharyngeal phase defects, commonly from neurological or structural causes, and can present with nasal regurgitation or aspiration.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 347

choices.text: Extrinsic dysphagia due to a lesion outside the esophageal wall
Functional dysphagia due to hypomotility of the esophageal body

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia. Imaging reveals compression of the esophagus by an enlarged thyroid gland. Which of the following best describes the type and origin of her dysphagia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extrinsic dysphagia due to a lesion outside the esophageal wall

 

Correct. Dysphagia caused by external compression of the esophagus from structures outside the wall (such as thyroid enlargement, mediastinal tumors, cervical osteophytes, aortic aneurysm) is classified as extrinsic or compressive dysphagia. Thyroid lesions (including goiter, tumors, or Hashimoto’s thyroiditis) are a well-known cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intramural dysphagia due to cricopharyngeal spasm: Incorrect. Cricopharyngeal spasm is a hypermotility disorder involving the upper esophageal sphincter, considered a mural (wall) motility cause, but not relevant in this case of thyroid-related compression.

 

Option B. Intraluminal dysphagia due to esophageal carcinoma: Incorrect. Intraluminal causes include things within the lumen, such as foreign bodies, strictures, or tumors that block passage directly. However, in this case, the obstruction is external.

 

Option D. Functional dysphagia due to hypomotility of the esophageal body: Incorrect. Hypomotility disorders like achalasia or scleroderma cause functional or mural dysphagia, not compressive dysphagia due to a thyroid mass.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Dysphagia can result from intraluminal, mural, or extramural lesions; thyroid enlargement causes compressive dysphagia by pressing on the esophagus from outside the wall.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 347

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia that started with solids and now includes liquids. He also reports weight loss and intolerance to acidic foods. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation to evaluate his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Barium swallow with fluoroscopy

 

Correct. This patient’s history of progressive dysphagia (solids → liquids) and acid intolerance raises strong suspicion for malignancy or strictures, possibly with ulcerative changes. A barium swallow is particularly helpful in identifying malignancies, strictures, achalasia, diverticula, hiatus hernia, and motility disorders when combined with fluoroscopy or cineradiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophageal manometry: Incorrect. Manometry is ideal for evaluating motility disorders like achalasia or spasms, but it is not the first-line test in patients with suspected mechanical obstruction (like cancer or strictures).

 

Option C. pH monitoring: Incorrect. This is used primarily in suspected gastroesophageal reflux cases to evaluate acid reflux episodes, not in initial evaluation of progressive dysphagia with possible mass or structural lesion.

 

Option D) Chest X-ray: Incorrect. A chest X-ray can help exclude mediastinal or pulmonary causes, but it is nonspecific and lacks the sensitivity for diagnosing intrinsic esophageal pathology.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Barium swallow with fluoroscopy is the investigation of choice in evaluating progressive dysphagia to assess structural lesions like strictures, malignancies, and motility disorders.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 347

choices.text: Base of tongue – remove under local anesthesia with curved forceps
Posterior pharyngeal wall – remove using mirror examination
Upper esophagus – endoscopic removal under general anesthesia
Pyriform fossa – observe for spontaneous passage of coin

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the emergency with a history of accidental ingestion of a coin. X-ray shows the coin lodged just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter. Which of the following is the most likely site of impaction and the best approach for management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper esophagus – endoscopic removal under general anesthesia

 

Correct. The most common site for an esophageal foreign body to lodge is just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter, especially in children. Objects like coins, meat bolus, chicken bones, and disc batteries are common. Rigid esophagoscopy under general anesthesia is the standard treatment, especially in children or for impacted/larger foreign bodies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Base of tongue – remove under local anesthesia with curved forceps: Incorrect. While this is a valid technique for sharp objects (e.g., fish bones, needles) visible in the vallecula or base of tongue, it is not used for esophageal foreign bodies.

 

Option B. Posterior pharyngeal wall – remove using mirror examination: Incorrect. Mirror examination may help visualize objects like staples or pins lodged in the posterior pharynx, but this is not applicable for esophageal foreign bodies.

 

Option D. Pyriform fossa – observe for spontaneous passage of coin: Incorrect. Observation may be considered for very small and non-obstructive foreign bodies, but coins in the pyriform fossa or esophagus require endoscopic removal to prevent complications like perforation or migration.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The most common site of foreign body impaction in the esophagus is just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter; endoscopic removal under general anesthesia is the treatment of choice.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 348

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department after reportedly swallowing a metallic object while playing. On examination, the child is active and stable. X-ray confirms a coin lodged at the upper end of the esophagus. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the foreign body ingestion in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Playing while eating and mouthing behavior

 

Correct. The most common age group affected by food passage foreign bodies is children under 5 years, accounting for nearly 80% of cases. This is due to their tendency to put objects in their mouth, often worsened by playing while eating. Educating parents is key in prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Use of upper denture: Incorrect. This is a risk factor in elderly adults, as dentures reduce tactile sensation, making it easier for foreign bodies to be swallowed unnoticed.

 

Option B. Underlying esophageal stricture: Incorrect. Although strictures can lead to lodgement of food pieces, they are more common in adults with carcinoma or prior injury, not toddlers.

 

Option D. Suicide attempt in a psychotic patient: Incorrect. This applies to psychotic or mentally disturbed individuals, not young children. Intentional ingestion of objects for self-harm is not the concern here.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Foreign body ingestion in the food passage is most common in children under 5 due to mouthing behavior and playing while eating.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 348

choices.text: The most common site of lodgement is the bronchoaortic constriction
Sharp objects always lodge at the cardiac end of the esophagus
Cricopharyngeal sphincter is the most common site of foreign body lodgement
Once an object passes the cricopharyngeal sphincter, it never causes obstruction

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought after accidental ingestion of a coin. X-ray neck and chest shows the coin lodged at the level of the cricopharyngeal region. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding foreign body lodgement in the food passage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricopharyngeal sphincter is the most common site of foreign body lodgement

 

Correct. The most common site for foreign body lodgement in the food passage is at or just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter, particularly for flat objects like coins, due to anatomical narrowing and poor peristalsis at this site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common site of lodgement is the bronchoaortic constriction: Incorrect. While bronchoaortic constriction is a secondary narrowing, the most frequent site remains the cricopharyngeal sphincter.

 

Option B. Sharp objects always lodge at the cardiac end of the esophagus: Incorrect. Sharp or pointed objects can lodge anywhere in the esophagus, depending on their shape and orientation.

 

Option D. Once an object passes the cricopharyngeal sphincter, it never causes obstruction: Incorrect. Though many objects that pass the esophagus may exit via the rectum, some can still get stuck at other narrow points such as the pylorus, ileocecal junction, or sigmoid colon, especially if they are sharp or large.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The cricopharyngeal sphincter is the most common site for foreign body impaction in the esophagus, especially for flat objects like coins.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 348

choices.text: Perform indirect laryngoscopy and reassure the parents
Proceed with endoscopic evaluation under general anesthesia
Order only a chest X-ray and send the patient home if normal

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of sudden choking while eating. The child now has drooling of saliva, difficulty swallowing, and mild respiratory distress. Examination reveals tenderness in the lower part of the neck to the right of the trachea. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proceed with endoscopic evaluation under general anesthesia

 

Correct. A child with sudden choking, drooling, dysphagia, neck tenderness, and respiratory distress is likely to have a foreign body in the upper esophagus. In such cases, X-rays may be normal, especially if the object is radiolucent. If clinical suspicion is strong, endoscopic removal under general anesthesia is the correct next step to avoid complications like aspiration pneumonitis or laryngeal edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start antibiotics and observe for 24 hours: Incorrect. Antibiotics are not a substitute for removal. Observation is dangerous in the presence of total obstruction or respiratory symptoms.

 

Option B. Perform indirect laryngoscopy and reassure the parents: Incorrect. Indirect laryngoscopy may show pooling of secretions but does not exclude a foreign body. Reassurance without definitive diagnosis can delay appropriate care.

 

Option D. Order only a chest X-ray and send the patient home if normal: Incorrect. Normal X-ray does not rule out foreign body, especially if it is non-radio-opaque (e.g., food, plastic, thin bones). Endoscopic evaluation is mandatory if symptoms persist.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Strong clinical suspicion of a food passage foreign body—especially in a child with choking, drooling, and dysphagia—warrants prompt endoscopic evaluation even if imaging is normal.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 349

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is suspected to have swallowed a foreign body. X-ray neck (PA and lateral views) shows a round, radio-opaque object lying in the coronal plane on PA view and edge-on in the lateral view, located just below the cricopharynx. Which of the following is the most likely location and the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophagus – proceed with endoscopic removal

 

Correct. On PA X-ray, esophageal foreign bodies appear in the coronal plane, while in lateral view, they appear edge-on. This is opposite to tracheal foreign bodies, which appear in the sagittal plane on PA view due to vocal cord orientation. The location just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter is the most common site for food passage foreign body lodgement. Endoscopic removal under general anesthesia is the next step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trachea – confirm with barium swallow: Incorrect. Barium swallow is contraindicated in suspected foreign body ingestion as barium may spill into the airway, making endoscopy more difficult and increasing aspiration risk.

 

Option C. Trachea – treat conservatively if asymptomatic: Incorrect. Airway foreign bodies, even if temporarily asymptomatic, require prompt removal due to risk of sudden airway compromise.

 

Option D. Larynx – perform immediate tracheostomy: Incorrect. Tracheostomy is indicated only in life-threatening upper airway obstruction, not in a stable patient with a foreign body in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Esophageal foreign bodies appear in the coronal plane on PA X-ray and require endoscopic removal; barium swallow is avoided as it can hinder subsequent endoscopy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 350

choices.text: Continue observation and examine stools for the next few days
Administer purgatives to speed up battery expulsion
Plan for endoscopic or surgical removal due to high-risk features

questions.text: A 3-year-old child accidentally swallowed a disc battery 2 cm in size. X-ray shows the battery in the stomach 48 hours after ingestion. The child is asymptomatic, taking a normal diet, and has no abdominal tenderness. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plan for endoscopic or surgical removal due to high-risk features

 

Correct. A disc battery >1.5 cm in a child under 6 years that remains in the stomach for more than 48 hours is an indication for operative intervention due to risks like mucosal injury, perforation, and chemical burns. This case fits all the criteria, so removal is indicated even in an asymptomatic child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue observation and examine stools for the next few days: Incorrect. This is advised for non-sharp, non-toxic, and small objects that have crossed the pylorus, especially when the object is progressing. But in this case, the battery is large, and time threshold has been crossed.

 

Option B. Administer purgatives to speed up battery expulsion: Incorrect. Purgatives are contraindicated, as they can increase intestinal motility and risk perforation, especially with sharp or corrosive objects.

 

Option C. Immediate surgical removal via laparotomy: Incorrect. Surgery is not the first line unless there are complications like obstruction or perforation. First, endoscopic retrieval is attempted if feasible.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Foreign bodies such as large disc batteries (>1.5 cm) retained in the stomach for over 48 hours in young children require endoscopic or surgical removal due to risk of complications.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 350

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a history of coin ingestion 4 days ago. The child now has fever, neck swelling, and noisy breathing. Examination reveals tenderness over the lower neck and drooling of saliva. What is the most likely complication and appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perioesophageal cellulitis or abscess

 

Correct. A foreign body lodged in the cervical esophagus can lead to local infection, resulting in perioesophageal cellulitis or abscess, especially after a few days. Symptoms include fever, neck swelling, tenderness, drooling, and possibly noisy breathing due to inflammation near the airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheo-esophageal fistula: Incorrect. This is a rare complication and usually occurs later or in cases of corrosive injury or after prolonged pressure necrosis. It often presents with chronic cough or recurrent aspiration, not with neck swelling.

 

Option C. Ulceration with stricture formation: Incorrect. This is a late complication, seen with missed or overlooked foreign bodies. The current presentation is acute, with signs of infection.

 

Option D. Respiratory obstruction due to laryngeal edema: Incorrect. Laryngeal edema causes immediate respiratory distress and stridor. The presence of neck swelling, fever, and drooling points more toward a deep neck space infection like perioesophageal abscess.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Esophageal foreign bodies can lead to life-threatening complications such as perioesophageal abscess, respiratory obstruction, and perforation; early recognition and removal are critical.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 350

choices.text: Observe and advise parents to monitor stool for 3–4 days
Start antibiotics and repeat X-ray after 7 days
Plan immediate endoscopic removal of the battery

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after accidentally swallowing a disc battery. X-ray reveals the battery lodged in the esophagus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plan immediate endoscopic removal of the battery

 

Correct. Disc batteries lodged in the esophagus are medical emergencies. They can cause mucosal damage in 1 hour, muscle injury in 2–4 hours, and perforation within 8–12 hours. Therefore, prompt endoscopic removal is indicated regardless of symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observe and advise parents to monitor stool for 3–4 days: Incorrect. This is appropriate only if the battery has already passed into the stomach and the patient is asymptomatic. Observation is not suitable when the battery is lodged in the esophagus.

 

Option B. Start antibiotics and repeat X-ray after 7 days: Incorrect. Delaying removal for 7 days can be fatal due to risks of stricture, perforation, fistula, and mediastinitis. Antibiotics alone do not prevent complications.

 

Option D. Wait for 48 hours before attempting removal: Incorrect. The 48-hour wait applies to batteries in the stomach in asymptomatic children. In the esophagus, removal must be immediate.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Disc batteries lodged in the esophagus must be removed immediately due to rapid mucosal and muscular injury leading to serious complications like perforation and mediastinitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 352

choices.text: Administer papain followed by Foley catheter extraction
Push the bolus into the stomach with a wide-bore tube
Avoid blind interventions and proceed with endoscopic removal under direct vision
Use glucagon to relax the lower esophageal sphincter and allow spontaneous passage

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a meat bolus stuck in his esophagus. A junior resident suggests administering papain to dissolve the meat and glucagon to relax the lower esophageal sphincter. What is the most appropriate management step, based on standard recommendations?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Avoid blind interventions and proceed with endoscopic removal under direct vision

 

Correct. Current recommendations clearly advise against blind or chemical methods for foreign body removal in the esophagus. Direct visualization using endoscopy (rigid or flexible) is the safest and most effective method. Foley catheter techniques are risky due to potential aspiration, and blindly pushing the foreign body down can lead to perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer papain followed by Foley catheter extraction: Incorrect. Papain may digest the esophageal wall if the foreign body is retained, especially if it contains undigested bone fragments. Foley catheter removal is not recommended due to aspiration risk.

 

Option B. Push the bolus into the stomach with a wide-bore tube: Incorrect. Pushing foreign bodies down is unsafe and not advised, especially when the cause of impaction (e.g., stricture or ring) is unknown.

 

Option D. Use glucagon to relax the lower esophageal sphincter and allow spontaneous passage: Incorrect. Glucagon does not relax strictures or esophageal rings, and its use in this context is not effective or recommended.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Blind removal methods, chemical digestion, and pharmacologic relaxation should be avoided; esophageal foreign bodies must be removed under direct vision using endoscopy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 352

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with suspected esophageal foreign body presents to the emergency. He is unable to swallow solids and has retrosternal discomfort. On evaluation, he has cervical spine stiffness. Which of the following oesophagoscopic approaches is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexible oesophagoscopy with topical anesthesia and sedation

 

Correct. Flexible scopes can be used even in the presence of jaw-neck abnormalities, which prevent rigid oesophagoscopy. They are typically done with topical or mild sedation, are less invasive, and are suitable for outdoor settings. They allow visualization of esophagus, stomach, pylorus, and duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Rigid oesophagoscopy under general anesthesia: Incorrect. Although effective for sharp or impacted foreign bodies, rigid scopes cannot be used in patients with jaw-neck abnormalities, and they require hospital admission and general anesthesia.

 

Option C.  Attempt blind removal with forceps to avoid anesthesia: Incorrect. Blind attempts are unsafe, especially for foreign body removal, and can cause perforation or push the object further. Always use direct vision.

 

Option D. Rigid oesophagoscopy with nasopharyngeal route: Incorrect. Rigid scopes are introduced orally, not nasally. Transnasal approach is possible only with flexible scopes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Flexible oesophagoscopy is preferred in jaw-neck abnormalities and for diagnostic purposes due to ease, safety, and ability to visualize beyond the esophagus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 351
